The basic idea of making a hierarchy page is to have a proper flow of members in an organization. It enables visualization and helps in altering the hierarchy of users in an organization.

This page enables the user to visualize the designation hierarchy and where a user comes in its organizational hierarchy. It also helps define which designation is at what level in that organization. This definition of designation level is used to set who can be the manager of whom. eg. if designation VP is set above Director then only a user of VP designation can be the manager of a user with Director designation and so on. ​User Management | Key Terms Used:
Default hierarchy is Manager → Associate until not changed manually.
The last node on the designation will be treated as SALES_ASSOCIATE and only the SALES_ASSOCIATE role can be assigned to this designation.
In the designation tree, only one designation can be below another designation (Linear Tree) i.e. In the hierarchy tree, no two designations can be on the same level.
This default hierarchy is an assumption and can be edited post org creation from the user manager’s hierarchy page.
Default hierarchy is the assumed hierarchy that is at least followed by any sales organization the assumption is a two-tier hierarchy of manager → associate
Users of Manager designation will not have a manager by default.
Users of Associate Designation must have a team and manager of “manager“designation
This hierarchy will have the following restrictions to a user
Designation of a user: The user can have only allowed the designation which is manager and associate by default.
Manager: The user can only have a manager of just above designation in the hierarchy tree. For example, users of associate designation can have a manager of “manager“ designation only.
Special case If the user is of top most designation then the user will not have any manager.
Team:- Users of the last designation must be added to the team to fulfill the prerequisites of Analysis.
Org 0 should have default hierarchy configuration JSON
Default hierarchy is decided from the organization configuration of 0th organization
select oc.property_value from organization_configuration oc where oc.organization_id =0 and property_name ='organization_hierarchy';
select oc.property_value from organization_configuration oc where oc.organization_id =0 and property_name ='organization_hierarchy';
The first user ie the contact user is added to the highest designation which is manager by assumption.
The hierarchy configuration JSON is stored in the organization_configuration  table for every organization with property_name ='organization_hierarchy'
After making an organization the next step is to make users inside the organization.
Now here comes the important part to be followed. As per the list, the first user created will be the top member in the hierarchy.
The designation is the new field that is added while creating the users.
While creating the users, the hierarchy should be followed i.e. Manager is the first member of the organization and after the creation of the Manager, the next member is the Associate by default.

This flow is made to make an easier approach towards the basic functionality of the organization so that tracking of reportee(s)  can be done easily and assigning and un-assigning users to a manager can be done easily.
Only those designations are allowed which are present in organization_config
Designation cannot be changed after creation to change designation user need to be promoted or demoted.
Users can edit the designation hierarchy tree from the Hierarchy page to add/remove allowed designations.
Default designation tree is set to Manager → Associate which is added to org config during organization creation.
Redis Cache needs to be updated for all reportees and subscribers of the user.

This option is visible if the to-be promoted user is not the last designation as he does not need replacement as he/she is not managing anyone. (Note: current default hierarchy of Two-Tier does will always fail this requirement)
This option allows choosing which manager of the same designation (who are licensed and active)  will replace this user as manager of his/her reportee(s).
This option is visible when to be promoted is not being promoted to highest (Note: current default hierarchy of Two-Tier does will always fail this requirement)
These options allow users to choose a new manager he/she will be reporting to

This option contains names of those users whose designation is one level above to be promoted designation. For eg if TL is promoted to Director then options would be all VP(s) (who are licensed and active).
This option will always be visible as anyone who is demoted will be a manager
On shifting user name from left dual select box to right
Redis cache will be updated i.e. list of subscribers and reportees

If the user is in the last designation then the user will automatically be assigned to one of the teams of that manager. The user is in the last designation, the user will automatically be assigned to one of the manager's team
User designation will be updated to the designation below in the designation tree of what it was assigned under.
On shifting user’s name from right to left will un-assign the user
The user is not assigned to any manager or team i.e. no one can see his/her report at this time.
If the unassigned user is not the last designation then he can see his reportee(s) reports but no user of the above designation can see his reports (if any) or his/her reportees.
Renaming designation will remain all users of that designation in that organization
Delete designation will set user designation to null.
Creating a designation will just create a designation in that organization without any user of that designation.
In the available reportee list, all the users whose designation is null and users having no manager and below designation is shown.
On deleting a designation all the users of that designation will now have the NULL designation.
Users of null designation will be available for assignment for every designation.
This may cause the hierarchy tree to break.
Delete designation should only be enabled when all users for that particular designation level are deleted.
On creating a designation we won’t have any user in that designation.

Salesken provides a product where users can make calls and SMSs and see their activities in form of multiple reports such as activity logs, signals and cue analysis. But some of our client they do not use our product to communication with the customer they wanted to use the product as a reporting perspective.
Salesken provides multiple reports to the managers and associate for evaluation and enhancement in their selling practices. ​Reporting

The solution is very straightforward that Salesken has to provide a way where user(with admin role) can authorize us to fetch or sync the calls and SMSs from the third party applications. In this documentation we will be focusing on RingCentral dialer Integration.

RingCentral provides businesses with different cloud-based business communications solutions that include message, video, phone, and contact center services. RingCentral stores all the call and SMSs details made through his platform.
Create an developer account on RingCentral Platform then we are all set to create the app.

The next step is to create the rest API app. While creating the app provide the App Name, App Description, Display Name, Summary, App Icon, OAuth Redirect URI, and Permission(e.g. Call Read, SMS Read, Account Read etc.).
In the next step you have to complete the requirements to get the app published.
In Authorization, first we have added an option to authorize Salesken to to pull calls and SMSs from RingCentral on integration page.
Click on DETAILS button will redirect users to either on authorize page or debugs page depending the the authorize status.
If user is already authorized then it will redirect to debug page else on RingCentral authorize page.
After the successful authorization we schedule a hourly Cron-Job (on GCP), and store the auth details in cdr_provider table in Salesken database then the users will redirect to debugs page.
Cron Job is created on google scheduler after the successful auth. We schedule two Cron-Jon one for calls that run every hours and one is for SMSs that runs on every x:30 hours.
For the fetching the calls and SMSs hourly Cron-Jobs triggered on every hours and we pulls the calls and SMSs from the RingCentral for previous hours.
To pull the calls we follow the below steps
Calculate the time of start date and end date for which we need to pull data.
Fetch all the extensions from the RingCentral for the given access token. Each extension is assigned to some users.
From the Extensions we get the Contacts details.
Check if the RingCentral user exists in Salesken database
If not - then we don’t do anything.
If yes - then we pull the calls for the user.
When we found user exists in Salesken database the we pull the calls using the extension Id.
Then we fetch from and to number using phone number API, if not returned from the pull call API.
In next step we check if we get the call recording ID.
If not then we put dummy recording URL. Recording URL may be missing in case of voicemail or missed calls.
If yes then we fetch the recording using the call recording ID. That returns the bytes that we convert and upload in GCP and get the URL.
Insert the calls log object on the log elk index.
In Kafka consumer we fetch the call log from log elk index.
And then we check in Postgres database if we already pulled that entity or not.
If we haven't pulled that record then we check if the lead exists for that record or not.
If not then we create the lead for the record.
In next step we insert the data into Postgres database.
In the last step we analyze the record.
Note: Extensions and Call records are returned as pagination form.
To pull the SMSs we follow the below steps
If yes - then we pull the SMSs for the user.
When we found user exists in Salesken database the we pull the SMSs using the extension Id.
Then we fetch from and to number using phone number API, if not returned from the pull SMS API.
Insert the SMS log object on the log elk index.

Salesken was built after the founding spent over 10 years training over 20,000 freshers into the sales ROLE.  The team went through all forms of training sales reps from classroom training to canned content, live voice bots, post analytics and eventually landed on real time cueing during a live sales call as the best way to help close a sale and improve sales rep productivity.
Sales Reps - primary persona, includes SDRs, AES, Inside sales reps - anyone selling over a recorded call or video conferencing solution
Sales Manager - secondary persona but decision maker and champion for Salesken within an organisation.  They include Head of Sales, VP sales, CROs, CGOs etc
Training, enablement and operations personas - These are influencers in the purchase decision and are a team of enablers focussed on improving sales productivity
Focussed on relationship, discipline towards making sales calls, do not usually have strong technical background and hence struggle to understand
Do not understand conversation mechanics, tend to jump into the pitch without understand sufficient context
Proactive cues on Opening, Lead Qualification, Need discovery, Closing, Selling best practises cues
Job requires several calls per day in a repeat motion every day, leading to monotony, robotic nature of delivering the pitch. This prevents personalisation of the calls

Most sales funnels convert at a small percentage, so the sales reps deal with a lot of rejection. It is hard for the sales reps to stay motivated and bring positive energy into every call.  Reps get desensitized on their calls.
(VP Sales, CROs, other head of sales designations)
Training is hard to measure as assessment models are not designed for scale in a task based work context.

training effectiveness is challenged by the mechanics, where sales reps are unable to remember finer details of the classroom training at the right moments on the call. Learning to sell is a lot like learing to drive - it cannot be acquired in a classroom or through a book or graphs. Task based training needs to be experiential for it to be effective.
Problem Statement: High complexity of skills required for selling <> Low skilled sales reps

Selling is the ability to influence the mind of another human to buy a product/ concept being sold , which established when the potential buyer feels a) understood b) finds a platform to express and reveal his pain points, concerns c) feels positive and high energy d) gets excited by the product being sold e) has confidence in the sales rep.

Influencing the mind of a stranger on the call is at the crux of selling. After analysing data of several million calls, Salesken has been able to detect patterns in winning conversations that seem to work in an industry/ product agnostic sense. An ideal sales call playbook as as per the chart below, from the data across a large dataset of winning calls.

From the above chart, it is clear that at different stages of the sales call, best sales reps bring in different technical and soft components to the conversation. We call stages of a call as playbook dimensions in Salesken. Some examples of this are illustrated below:

However, the need discovery stage requires the sales reps to have a more consultative approach and listen, with empathy to the customers response to the queries asked. Product demo dimension requires sales reps to have very high technical knowledge and demonstrate confidence. Closing requires sales reps to create a sense of urgency around the next steps.

Sales reps struggle even with the technical parts of the product, as they are usually do not have strong technical backgrounds. The complexity of the products/ product suites and features sets are not entirely understood during the call. Consultative selling skills are mostly missing as most sales reps tend to dive straight into the product feature selling, without sufficiently investigating the customer pain point.

Sales is also a hunting activity, often leading to failure and rejection. Funnel conversion rates are barely over 10% points, which means on a sales reps get rejected on atleast 9 out of the 10 calls are rejections. Sales reps struggle to motivate themselves after a bad call and continue to bring positive energy, confidence and passion into all of their calls and the repetitive nature of this tends to make the calls sound scripted and robotic and not personalised.
To summarise, sales reps face the following challenges:
Low Technical expertise - challenge in remembering complex product technical details

Low Conversational expertise - skills required in getting a customer to reveal context often involve questioning gently, building rapport, personalizing, high empathy to the problem, and building credibility as the problem expert - all of which are missing

Personalising through monotony - Sales reps tend to make a large number of calls per day and the nature of the jobs tends to get monotonous. It is difficult for the reps to personalise the conversation to the sales rep and often fall into a generic one size fits all pitch. The best sales reps however are able to dynamically rework their generic pitch into the context of the persona they are selling to.

Constant rejection, mostly solo/ lonely effort - the nature of sales funnels are that sales reps have to deal with constant rejection, in what is often a solitary pursuit of a win. This requires sales reps to find motivation, mostly from competitive forces, fear or their own inner drive to create and script wins.
Due to the above, there seems to be a significant difference in the lead conversion numbers between the best sales reps and the remaining sales reps.

The lead conversion losses between the best sales reps and the rest of the reps is what we call “preventable losses”. Preventable losses can largely be attributed to the differences in how sales conversations are had by various sales reps across the team.

We have seen preventable losses for customers for various segments go upto potentally 200%, Salesken has potential to massively improve the topline by even a small closing of gap in the preventable losses. The way Salesken does this through democratising the intelligence found in winning calls across all sales conversations and improving the conversion numbers across the funnel. Customers using salesken cues have seen their conversion numbers improve by 25%-200%
Salesken was designed to help the sales reps solve for these challenges. After analysing millions of sales calls, Salesken’s cueing engine works to assist sales reps in the following ways:
Generic cues : Soft talk, motivation cues designed to help sales reps have confidence, be motivated, reminder on voice, energy, dealing with rejection etc

Playbook cues : Script related knowledge hooks designed to help sales reps through the details of the script the sales reps may not remember. Playbook cues come off a knowledge graph built by Salesken and provide the script inputs from the above chart across all dimensions of opening, lead qualification, need discovery, product demo, closing etc.
Intelligence cues : These cues are from the best practises observed by Salesken’s ai engines out of winning calls, including best responses on objections, FAQs, best selling features etc

Emotion cues: Salesken models 28 different emotions under 6 major groups to assist sales reps with all emotional intelligence required during a call including empathy, positivity, confidence, satifaction, joy, worry etc
All FAQ knowledge graph cues (Product, objection handling, KVP)
Proactive cues on Opening, Lead Qualification, Need discovery, Closing, Selling best practices cues

The engineering involved includes receiving live audio streams of voice, adding transcription layers, accessing intelligence within the system, both generic and high context and bringing the assistance to the final end user - the sales rep - in short easily digestible formats called ‘cues’, that are designed to be consumed during a live interaction. The complexity of a sales call involves hard and soft elements around nudging the lead towards a close - as seen below.

All the services can be deployed using Jenkins Pipeline or Manually as well.
The services are configured in Azure App Services

[ Azure Web Apps is a cloud computing-based platform for hosting websites, created and operated by Microsoft. It is a platform as a service that allows publishing Web apps running on multiple frameworks and written in different programming languages, including Microsoft proprietary ones and 3rd party ones. ]
We have used Jenkins Parameters to parametrize variables.
Log in to Jenkins (http://20.85.190.85/) with username and Password Shared.
Inside Applications Folder we have a separate pipeline for all applications.
Select any Service which you want to deploy, For Eg. analysis
Click on analysis → On the left click on “build with Parameters”
The default parameters are already configured we can manually fill them as well.
Click on the build ( button at bottom of the screen )
You can also see build logs by going to console output
Steps to set-up and run comm project on local :
Download the comm repo from below : ​https://github.com/salesken-tech/comm - Connect your Github account git clone git@github.com:salesken-tech/comm.git
Open comm in Eclipse and Import comm :File → Import → Maven → Existing Maven ProjectsSelect the project folder of comm and then click on Finish to import it on the workspace
In Project Explorer, right click on the <project_name> → Show in Local Terminal → Terminal
Run → mvn clean install [If it throws any error, make sure your JAVA_HOME path is set properly]

Setup Tomcat on Eclipse : For configuring the tomcat server in eclipse IDE, click on servers tab at the bottom side of the IDE → right click on blank area → New → Servers → Under Apache, choose tomcat version →  next → click on Browse button → select the apache tomcat root folder previous to bin → next → addAll → Finish

From Project Explorer, right click on the project, Run As → Run On Server [If this option doesn’t show up, double check if you have any  other instance of comm/tomcat running anywhere on your local system]
Click on Finish. It’ll start comm on localhost:8080.You can test if it’s up using the API as : http://localhost:8080/comm

Project flow : The proxy call originates from appie and flows through comm via the API endpoint/v1/proxy/call (ProxyCallServiceImpl). This is followed by a call to makeProxyCall() in ProxyCallFactory where the code for the given provider(eg. twilio, salesken, plivo, etc) is executed. The last piece of code to get executed before the call is transferred to cpaas is makeProxyCall() in SaleskenProxyCallDaoImpl which then calls the cpaas API exposed in the db.properties file.

When an inbound call is received Vonage makes a request to a publicly accessible URL of Our choice we call this the answer URL. You need to create a webhook server that is capable of receiving this request  and returning the NCCO containing a connect action that will forward the call to PSTN phone number . we can do this b y extracting the destination number from the to query params and returning it to the response.
1.Create a new project directory in a destination of your and change into it and initialize a new node.js project by running the CMD
npm init-y.

The First part creates an Express server and makes it available locally on 3000 .the server exposes 2 paths:
a. /voice/answer is the answer_url it sends back the JSON response containing the destination number for the call.
b. /voice/event ,will set destination for vonage to notify everything happens during the call we call this as event _url.

Amazon Connect is a contact center which can be used to make or receive calls and also stores the CDRs. We will fetch the data from Amazon Connect at a regular interval and process it.
In this scenario, a Scheduler will be invoked every fixed interval of time. Then using Amazon Connect SDK we will fetch the call details from the Amazon Connect of a given time range.

Cron Job is created on google scheduler. There will be two tasks, one is for creating a cloud task and another one is to delete a cloud task. The scheduler will invoke for every fixed interval of time. Based on this we will schedule a Cron Job on google cloud scheduler. The scheduler will call for an API to retrieve the call details from the dialer with some time range/limit. Then dialer will fetch all call details of the given time range. The cronjob is created when the organization is onboarded for Amazon Connect.
The above request returns all the CDR within the specified start and end date in a json array.

The cron job url hits the Amazon Connect servlet at regular intervals. The call data fetched from Amazon Connect is transformed to PulledCall object and is pushed to Elk for logging. OrgId:callSid is then pushed to the kafka producer. The message queue listener then consumes this and processes the call detail record to make a lead, sales contact person and task, if not already existing.
To prehend suggest signals for an organization when an organization is created and regularly by scraping data from conversations to help customers define signals for their product.
To scrape the website of the organization and suggest signals when a default product is made during org creation flow.
Request and response will be stored in the logger database.
The latest job_id corresponding to the product will be persisted in the database for future use and extraction of data.
The response to the webhook will be pre-processed to check if there are no special characters in the signal and dimension name
If no dimension name is present then the dimension name will be the same as the signal name.
Then the data will be persisted in the database avoiding deduplication.

Sampark is a dialer which can be used to make or receive calls and also stores the CDRs. We will fetch the data from Sampark at a regular interval and process it.
In this scenario, a Scheduler will be invoked every fixed interval of time. Then using Sampark’s API we will fetch the call details from the Sampark of a given time range.

Cron Job is created on google scheduler. There will be two tasks, one is for creating a cloud task and another one is to delete a cloud task. The scheduler will invoke for every fixed interval of time. Based on this we will schedule a Cron Job on google cloud scheduler. The scheduler will call for an API to retrieve the call details from the dialer with some time range/limit. Then dialer will fetch all call details of the given time range. The cron job is created when the organization is onboarded for Sampark.
The above request returns a token which is to be used as the Authorization header in the fetch call API.

The cron job url hits the sampark servlet at regular intervals. The call data fetched from Sampark is transformed to PulledCall object and is pushed to Elk for logging. OrgId:callSid is then pushed to the kafka producer. The message queue listener then consumes this and processes the call detail record to make a lead, sales contact person and task, if not already existing.
Fresh Sales in one of the trending CRM in current market. With this doc we will describe about how  to create a account on this CRM and how it will be integrated with our product.
Creating a new account on freshsales CRM :
Following is the process of creating new user on Freshsales CRM:
The behaviour of the Freshsales CRM to test the APIs and other CRM related functionality.
Freshsales CRM to test the APIs is divided into three parts:
user will signup and create a trial account into the Freshsales CRM.
user will create contact and add tasks for the newly made contact.
user will test the API available in the developers section of Freshsales API collection for CRM.
Part - I : Signup and Creation of trial account

Approach : The idea is to establish a conference call between multiple legs, using Asterisk. To start with, we establish a call between an agent and a customer using ARI(s). There’s a unique callSid saved for this call on Elastic search. Once this is achieved, we enable barging in of another leg(say, a Manager wants to jump in on to the call), fetching the same callSid from Elastic Search, and generating further new call legs. The Conference(barge) call request is intercepted by the API exposed on CPAAS, the corresponding logic is written in AsterCallControl to create a new channel for conference and add it on the same bridge as that of agent and customer.

Below are the curls:To establish a call between an Agent and a Customer:curl --location --request POST 'http://localhost:8084/call/proxy' \--header 'AUTH_API_KEY: S@al34swfrWEasd' \--header 'Content-Type: application/json' \--data-raw '{"toNumber": "09534563317","fromNumber": "09748837736","callerId": "08068840026","providerId" : 3}'

To barge some other leg on that same conference call : curl --location --request POST 'http://localhost:8084/barge' \--header 'AUTH_API_KEY: abcd123456' \--header 'Content-Type: application/json' \--data-raw '{"callSid": "8adc7d00-7774-4dbb-ba24-15f7c3254193","callerId": "08068840026","number":"09845287363"}'

To use the Microsoft identity platform endpoint, you must register your app using the Azure app registration portal. You can use either a Microsoft account or a work or school account to register an app.
Sign in to the Azure Portal using either work or school account or a personal Microsoft account.
In the left-hand navigation pane, select the Azure Active Directory service, and then select App registrations > New registration
When the Register an application page appears, enter your application's registration information like name, supported account type and redirect uri.

Credentials are used by confidential client applications that access a web API. Examples of confidential clients are web apps, other web APIs, or service-type and daemon-type applications. Credentials allow your application to authenticate as itself, requiring no interaction from a user at runtime. You can add both certificates and client secrets (a string) as credentials to your confidential client app registration.
In the Azure portal, in App registrations, select your application.
Select Certificates & secrets > Client secrets > New client secret.
Select an expiration for the secret or specify a custom lifetime.
Once you've registered both your client app and web API and you've exposed the API by creating scopes, you can configure the client's permissions to the API by following these steps:
If you have access to multiple tenants, use the Directory + subscription filter in the top menu to select the tenant containing your client app's registration.
Select Azure Active Directory > App registrations, and then select your client application
Select API permissions > Add a permission > My APIs.
Select the web API you registered as part of the prerequisites : Delegated permissions
Under Select permissions, expand the resource whose scopes you defined for your web API, and select the permissions the client app should have on behalf of the signed-in user.
Permissions Required for Email Integration : User.Read, Mail.ReadBasic.All, Mail.Read, Mail.ReadWrite, offline_access.
2. GETTING ACCESS TOKEN FOR THE USER WITH PERMISSIONS

To use Microsoft Graph to read and write resources on behalf of a user, your app must get an access token from the Microsoft identity platform and attach the token to requests it sends to Microsoft Graph. One common flow used by native and mobile apps and also by some Web apps is the OAuth 2.0 authorization code grant flow.

The first step to getting an access token for many OpenID Connect (OIDC) and OAuth 2.0 flows is to redirect the user to the Microsoft identity platform /authorize endpoint.With the Microsoft identity platform endpoint, permissions are requested using the scope parameter. In this example, the Microsoft Graph permissions requested are User.Read and Mail.Read, which will allow the app to read the profile and mail of the signed-in user. The offline_access permission is a standard OIDC scope that is requested so that the app can get a refresh token. The app can use the refresh token to get a new access token when the current one expires.

2.2 Consent ExperienceAfter sending an authorization request, the user will be asked to enter their credentials to authenticate with Microsoft. The Microsoft identity platform v2.0 endpoint will also ensure that the user has consented to the permissions indicated in the scope query parameter. If the user hasn't consented to any of those permissions and if an administrator hasn't previously consented on behalf of all users in the organization, they'll be asked to consent to the required permissions.

2.3 Authorization ResponseIf the user consents to the permissions your app requested, the response will contain the authorization code in the code parameter. Here's an example of a successful response to the previous request. Because the response_mode parameter in the request was set to query, the response is returned in the query string of the redirect URL.
2.4 Get a TokenYour app uses the authorization code received in the previous step to request an access token by sending a POST request to the /token endpoint.
Although the access token is opaque to your app, the response contains a list of the permissions that the access token is good for in the scope parameter.
2.6 Use the access token to call Microsoft
After you have an access token, you can use it to call Microsoft Graph by including it in the Authorization header of a request. The following request gets the profile of the signed-in user.
A successful response will look similar to the following (some response headers have been removed)
2.7 Use the refresh token to get a new access token

Access tokens are short lived, and you must refresh them after they expire to continue accessing resources. You can do so by submitting another POST request to the /token endpoint, this time providing the refresh_token instead of the code.
2.8 Saving access credentials of the user in the backend
Once we get the access_token of the user from /token endpoint , we save his/her credentials in user_setting table for future use.

The body of the message. It can be in HTML or text format. Find out about safe HTML in a message body.
The first 255 characters of the message body. It is in text format.
The ID of the conversation the email belongs to.
Indicates the position of the message within the conversation.
The date and time the message was created.
The date and time information uses ISO 8601 format and is always in UTC time. For example, midnight UTC on Jan 1, 2014 is 2014-01-01T00:00:00Z.
The flag value that indicates the status, start date, due date, or completion date for the message.

The owner of the mailbox from which the message is sent. In most cases, this value is the same as the sender property, except for sharing or delegation scenarios. The value must correspond to the actual mailbox used. Find out more about setting the from and sender properties of a message.

Indicates whether the message has attachments. This property doesn't include inline attachments, so if a message contains only inline attachments, this property is false. To verify the existence of inline attachments, parse the body property to look for a src attribute, such as .

Unique identifier for the message. By default, this value changes when the item is moved from one container (such as a folder or calendar) to another. To change this behavior, use the Prefer: IdType="ImmutableId" header. See Get immutable identifiers for Outlook resources for more information. Read-only.
The importance of the message. The possible values are: low, normal, and high.
The classification of the message for the user, based on inferred relevance or importance, or on an explicit override. The possible values are: focused or other.

A collection of message headers defined by RFC5322. The set includes message headers indicating the network path taken by a message from the sender to the recipient. It can also contain custom message headers that hold app data for the message.
Returned only on applying a $select query option. Read-only.
The message ID in the format specified by RFC2822.
Indicates whether a read receipt is requested for the message.
Indicates whether the message is a draft. A message is a draft if it hasn't been sent yet.
The date and time the message was last changed.
The unique identifier for the message's parent mailFolder.
The date and time the message was received.

The account that is actually used to generate the message. In most cases, this value is the same as the from property. You can set this property to a different value when sending a message from a shared mailbox, for a shared calendar, or as a delegate. In any case, the value must correspond to the actual mailbox used. Find out more about setting the from and sender properties of a message.
The date and time the message was sent.

The part of the body of the message that is unique to the current message. uniqueBody is not returned by default but can be retrieved for a given message by use of the ?$select=uniqueBody query. It can be in HTML or text format.
The URL to open the message in Outlook on the web.

You can append an ispopout argument to the end of the URL to change how the message is displayed. If ispopout is not present or if it is set to 1, then the message is shown in a popout window. If ispopout is set to 0, then the browser will show the message in the Outlook on the web review pane.
The message will open in the browser if you are logged in to your mailbox via Outlook on the web. You will be prompted to login if you are not already logged in with the browser.
This URL cannot be accessed from within an iFrame.

The ADMIN can control the setting in admin settings for Primary Calling Method to be Conference.If the Conference is selected as a Calling method, This enables associate to make an outbound call as a conference call.Additional features have now been introduced in Conference calling called Call Controls for a Manager. This allows Manager to do multiple functions over ongoing calls. They see all the ongoing calls in the Call Controls page and can choose to:1. Barge:Call Barging is a feature that allows Manager to drop in on live calls between the Customer and the Associate. Once the Manager joins the call, an announcement happens in the call which is heard only by Associate, that only lets the Associate know that Manager has joined the call.This feature gives the advantage to the manager/supervisor to ensure the call quality and also coach the agents.2. Listen:Call Listen allows a Manager to listen into live calls between the Customer and the Associate.  Once the Manager joins the call, an announcement happens in the call which is heard only by Associate, that only lets the Associate know that Manager has joined the call.This feature gives the advantage to the manager/supervisor to observe and ongoing call and gather feedback points to improve quality of the calls.3. Whisper:Call Whisper is a feature that allows Manager to join in on live calls between the Customer and the Associate, but only the Associate can listen Manager’s voice. Once the Manager joins the call, an announcement happens in the call which is heard only by Associate, that only lets the Associate know that Manager has joined the call.This feature gives the advantage to the manager/supervisor to give live instructions to the agents.Developers: Yash

Ring Central Calls Fetch by Date FilterThis is a new API that gives us ability to fetch/sync all calls from Ring Central on basis of a requested timeline, which was earlier constrained by a limited default duration. Developers: Sarthak

This document serves as the UX + Dev design guideline for the “Selling best practices” set of dimensions in the product.
Considering that there are 100 conversations, as an example:
For each 1 conversation in 100 conversations, check for presence or absence of a dimension. If present, then +1. Assuming the dimension is “Confidence” for this flow.

Aggregate all these scores - if the score is above 50, then aggregate confidence is “good” and if the score is below 50, then “poor”.  In this representation, there is no “average”. Only “Good” and “Poor”. For the purpose of this set of dimensions, we recommend a 60-40 split for good-poor, rather than 50-50.

After several rounds of experimentation and small-scale A/B testing with light and dark UX, we concluded that it is recommended to follow the current light UX background and palette.

The dimensions are given unique colours (subject to change based on brand recommendations) based on colour psychology resources researched. Hence, the card(s) for each of the eight dimensions have elements in the colour that’s mapped to these dimensions.
Instead of further dropdowns inside “script analysis” and “selling best practices”, since there are too many sub-trees for a user to navigate;
the user can go to “Selling Best Practices”, and within that screen, can use the tabs and other ways as shown in the section “A Note on Navigation” above to navigate amongst Dimensions and Overview.
Each of these icons represents a dimension. Each icon is clickable. Each dimension is represented by a colour.

Manual Tasks we do while creating a new infra and How can we automate it
Here is a list of some Manual Tasks which are overwhelming and Time-consuming as well during a new setup:
Every time we need to create some Instances / VM to host our services.
We need to do manual configurations related to tomcat and Java in instances.
We need to change db.properties in services ( Changing this in one service is fine but doing the same thing in 10 services is a big hack)
Creation of Instances can be automated using Terraform scripts (No Manual Efforts)
We can utilize Ansible or shell scripts to make required configurations in instances.
Ansible or shell scripts to make required configurations in instances
We need to utilize either environmental variables or some managed services from the cloud for secrets management.
managed services from the cloud for secrets management
Why are Environmental variables not managed services?
As Environmental variables are easy to configure and fewer code changes are required.

As we are providing on-premise deployments to some big giants (ICICI) which may not allow us to use anything coming from a public domain, It will not feasible for us to use a cloud-native solution for this.
not allow us to use anything coming from a public domain
We are frequently migrating to different cloud services so, It will be difficult to manage secrets in each cloud offering.

Alignment: Verify that dynamic elements align and space correctly.
Width: Check whether each element's width adapts to the viewport.

Height: This is usually unchanged in responsive design, but for some cases, you might specify element height relative to the viewport (like Menu or Edit buttons) on mobile devices. Test this on different mobile browsers and orientations.
Spacing and padding: Verify that elements don't overlap.
Conditional rendering: Test that elements can appear, hide, and resize based on viewport size, dynamically.

We currently have two major problem sets:1. If customer wants to analyse a call recording by himself, there is no way on our platform to do this.2. During onboarding a new client or during Customer trials, there is a huge pain which our business/operations team has to undergo in getting customer call recordings uploaded and analysed.This has a huge dependency on technology team and thereby impacts timelines.This feature provides a self-serve way through the Manager’s account to upload a call recording by themselves for an associate, which will then be submitted for analysis automatically.Once analysed, these recordings will be visible in the Activity log, as Call Type: FILE UPLOADEDThis recording will be analysed like any other call, and hence will have necessary signals, and all the meta data associated with the call.

Activity Log (Field Addition)As part of the Activity log download, there is a new field that has been added called “end Time”.Previously, if our customers wanted to query on the actual end Time of the call, they had to add up manually the start Time and the handling time.This was a cumbersome process. With the addition of this new field, customers have direct access to the end Time value in the downloaded version of Activity log.Developers: Vishaldeep

The above Curl endpoint which is used to place an outbound call for CpaaS and asterisk call control Application .After importing the above CURL by hitting a post request the outbound call would be established between the two numbers and the corresponding logs will be running on the Application Console.
1.toNumber:  The Destination number to which the call will arrives to the End User. Append 0 before an indian number when hitting an endpoint
2.fromNumber: The Source number from which you can make a call .make sure to append 0 before hitting an Endpoint.
3.Callerid: Allows you to see an incoming caller’s name and number before you answer.
4.Providerid: An unique identification number which is set as 3 by default
5.AUTH_API_KEY: An Auth Api key to be added in header section for Authentication purpose before making an authenticated Api Call request .

Vicidial is a telephony solution designed to interact with Asterisk to implement outbound calls.The setup involves three major components: 1) Setting up a Http server - to host vicidial on localhost2)Setting up and configuring Asterisk - to enable outbound calls 3)Setting up a  MySQL server - to store call logs

To make an outbound call using ViciDial, we need to configure all three above components on Linux platform. We need to write in multiple Dialplans in Asterisk to make sure it understands and configures the calling facility. [Dialplan is a scripting language meant for Asterisk to enable voice calling using it. It enables the developers to control the call flow and route the calls between different users based on the script and configuration]

VICIDIAL is an Open Source Under AGPL V2.0 Licence  Software Suite that is designed to interact with Asterisk Open source PBX Phone System to act as a Complete inbound/outbound Contact centre suite with inbound email support as well to Extend the functionality of phone and System.
The Asterisk System that has a Zap/DAHDI(T1/E1/PSTN) teleco lines or VOIP (IAX /SIP )trunks and many different kinds of Softphones and hard phones as well

VIC DIAL can dial predictively at a ratio one call at a time .ASTGUI client a GUI Client Application was created for more advanced features of Asterisk to be used by anyone using even a single line phone.
Vicidial has an Agent API and Non-Agent Api this classes are intended to use in PHP
Scripts are made up of PERL and PHP. It uses MYSQL as it’s Database Server Apache/Httpd for its Front End web interface and Linux as its operating System.
The Latest version of VICIDial uptodate is  2.2 release candidate 7.
●      Inbound, Outbound Blended Call, Email & Chat Handling
Asterisk Server (version - 1.2,1.4, 11 and 13) with proper S/w installed
4.MYSQL 5.0 Server  or Greater Database Server (local/Remote)
Process flow of One call at a time call
All Components are installed and running (with Asterisk and MYSQL Servers)
GUI assigns a Open Meetme extension to the user called Session-id
GUI Sends a manger Command originate to connect to user to meetme ext
User clicks the DIAL NEXT NUMBER and GUI Updates first available call-to-number in DB to Pending Status
GUI Sends ORIGINATE Command to call the client’s number from meet me ext
User is talking to the client user transfers call to 3rd party, client Zap channel is REDIRECTed to 3rd party
Call is hung up and disconnected .user selects the disposition status
This system is dependant on a MySQL server(version 4.0.XX or higher) acting as the storage place of all data

and settings for the system. This was done so that it would be very scalable and flexible. This application draws  on a lot of the core scripting inside of the astGUIclient suite of applications and was built with flexibility in mind.
We have used VICIDIAL for over 3 years now on up to 160 seats at once across 7 separate Asterisk servers
all using the same MySQL server and dialling on the same campaign. It is important to keep in mind that
because VICIDIAL uses Asterisk meetme rooms for it’s dialling that the Asterisk server will see an increased
load as compared to a simple Zap/SIP-only calls.

Linux Operating System as its platform, without an operating system its nothing. You can choose from several distributions like Slackware Linux, Gentoo Linux, Ubuntu Server, CentOS, and OpenSuSe. For this document we will be using Ubuntu Server 8.0.4 LTS.
MySQL 5.0+, this is the “brain” of the entire system, this is where call logs are stored, agent login sessions, leads and other data, the later version comprises 106  tables.
Apache or Httpd web server, this is used mainly to provide access for the administration interface and for the agent interface, think of this as the window or a door or basically a front end
. 4. An IP PBX, VICIdial uses Asterisk Open-Source IPPBX as its means to dial and receive incoming calls.

Meetme Conference bridge module of asterisk as its way of bridging a call to an agent which I will explain more later. Meetme uses a timing device, can be a digium or sangoma hardware or basically ztdummy which comes with Zaptel or Dahdi tools.
Perl CPAN modules as its backend to communicate with the Asterisk Server, they tell asterisk to process calls, recordings, and send the data to the MYSQL Database.
The agent logs in through a web interface provided by the web server which is provided namely vicidial.php its usually default at this address: http://yourlocalipaddress/agc/vicidial.php

Then agent inputs phone login, password, agent username and password, credentials are being checked against the MySQL database to see if the agent and phone exists or not. If not an error is returned telling you that you have the wrong password or simply not displaying the list of campaigns you are allowed to login to.

If those credentials are correct, MySQL server then allocates a conference number from vicidial_conferences table to the agent, the asterisk server will then call the extension where the agent is connected, for example an agent uses cc100 to connect its softphone then the asterisk server will then calls cc100, the softphone receives the call, the agent answers it and automatically the agent is put into a MeetMe conference bridge. You will hear a voice telling you “You are the only person in this conference”.

Granting that leads are loaded for the campaign, the perl scripts are in charge of putting those leads into a hopper, a hopper acts like a buffer wherein the contents of the hopper are information, contents of the hopper are then sent to the Asterisk Server telling it to call those numbers that are in the hopper depending on the DIAL mode that is set in the campaign.

Once the agent is put into that campaign, the Asterisk Server then dials those numbers in the hopper, once a call is connected or is answered, automatically the Asterisk Server will bridge that call to a meetme conference where an agent is waiting.

Agent and called party now converses, once a call is hung up, its then written to the call logs and then the web interface popups a disposition interface for the agent to dispose of the call. If call recording is enabled, the recording scripts in the cron job will be processing it and it will be put default under /var/spool/asterisk/monitorDONE respectively.
At the end of the shift agent logs out, the MeetMe Conference bridge is destroyed and the conference table in the database is updated and the agent has logged out.

Server Hardware – Intel Core 2 Quad 3.0 ghz Processor, Intel Motherboard, 4 GB DDR2 800 Mhz RAM, Western Digital Raptor 320 GB 10,000 RPM SATA hard drive, 550 watts branded power supply (HEC, Gigabyte, Thermaltake, you choose), A full tower casing (Li-anLi, Gigabyte Poseidon). This build can cost around 30,000 – 40,000 pesos or around 600 or 800USD the last time I set up one of this kind.

Ubuntu Server 8.0.4 LTS 64 bit Linux Operating System – Since this is a stand alone server, a 64-bit version would be really nice, in my deployments using a 64 bit operating system I see a performance increase in MySQL and Apache web servers, asterisk performance hardly had an increase, also on the other hand 64 bit has good memory management, it can detect RAM which is higher than 3 GB flawlessly, for its other advantages you can look it up at google.

Asterisk 1.4.21.2 Version – VICIdial has also their own pre patched version of this asterisk release which I've been using recently, in my observation asterisk 1.4.21.2 version is much better in handling SIP carriers compared to asterisk 1.2.30.4 which is also another good version to use for VICIdial. For reliability and stability both are at par. My observations may differ from others though. But so far I have upgraded 87 servers to Asterisk 1.4.21.2 and they seem to be running fine without an issue till now.

Google.com – If ever you stumble upon issues during your installation there's always google for you to copy and paste the error, who knows there could be lots of you who are experiencing it too. ​http://www.vicidial.org/VICIDIALforum/

When prompted, type in the new root password a second time to verify it; If the password chosen is considered weak the system might complain that it is a ‘BAD PASSWORD’ but will still allow you to use it Please use secure passwords where possible. A strong password is at least 12 characters long and a mix of upper case, lower case, numbers, and special characters like ! % @ _ - ( ) etc. A randomly generated password string is the most secure but usually the most difficult to remember. Regardless of the password you choose please make sure you can remember the password. If the root password is lost then nothing can be done on the local system. It is not trivial to recover a lost root password and requires someone to physically be at the server during the recovery.

This project was created to handle and control the flow of outbound call established via cpaas and routed to a particular Asterisk server.

Below functionalities are implemented as part of it :1. outbound call using Asterisk - A connection is established with the Asterisk host on a specified port. Asterisk receives call events on a websocket, through which all the events are routed and are being captured by the call controller application. Based on the type of events, channels are created(one for the agent, one for the customer), and then bridged together to establish a call.
2.  call webhooks - Webhooks to show the progress of calls on an ELK dashboard.

Whenever we initiate a call from cpaas system, it goes on to an Asterisk host - this marks the legA(channel) of the call. Asterisk receives an event (onStasisStart) which is consumed by AsterCallControl over a websocket connection. There’s a ARIWSHelper class which caters to all the events received over the websocket, and from ClickToCall class, we keep on overriding those eventHandlers and write business logic to establish the call. Terminologies of a call : Channel - Two legs of the call - legA and legB are called channels, they represent the two parties, i.e., the agent and the customer respectively, in case of an outbound call.Bridge - The two channels are added to a bridge (created using ARI functions). Once the channels are added, the bridge merges the two channels, and places the call.
Present: Akash, Sunil, Sai, Rajan, Pankaj, Sudhir, Saurabh Y, Harkishan

The settings that can be configured are:- Route of Inbound Call: Web, Voicemail,  Redirect To Mobile, or a Web>Mobile>VoicemailThe associate will receive call on their Web Browser irrespective of which page they are on Salesken platform and they can choose to accept or reject the incoming call.Developers: Heet, Yash, Riya

Cues are a set of FAQs that are configured to assist Agent during a conversation with the customer.During a call with the customer, the associate is shown set of instructions at different points of time during the conversation.Manager can now see Cues related insights on a new report under Reports called Cues Analysis, where a Cue-wise summary can be seen for different cues that were detected. There is an option to apply filters in this report to filter by specific Agent(s) or Team(s).This report is only be visible if the ADMIN has enabled REAL TIME CUES in the admin settings for the whole organisation.Developers: Yashwant

There are multiple integrations now available on Salesken. The following integrations are now offered on the platform:- Salesforce- LeadSquared-  HubSpot- Aircall- Ziwo- FreshSales- Zoom- RingCentral- FonalityAll of these integrations have a feature of debug pages for the data that is synced. This can be viewed by the ADMIN of the organisation. The debug page can be used and is a quick utility to search the data that has been synced by a free-text search or simultaneously perform a filter by date.Developers: Entire Team
Now an ADMIN can perform an integration with Zoom on Salesken Platform.They can go to Settings, into Zoom section and connect their Zoom calls seamlessly.

Once Zoom Authentication is done, any zoom call that takes palce will automatically be ingested into the Salesken platform.The Insights for the Zoom calls will be available same as any other call that takes place on the Salesken platform, without any difference.Developers: Varun
Now an ADMIN can perform an integration with Ring Central on Salesken Platform.They can go to Settings, into Ring Central section and connect their Ring Central calls and SMS seamlessly.

Once Ring Central Authentication is done, there is a periodic sync of Ring Central calls and SMS into the Salesken platform.The Insights for the Ring Central calls and SMS will be available same as any other call that takes place on the Salesken platform, without any difference.Developers: Saurabh, Sarthak

Now every Associate can integrate their Google Calendar on Salesken Platform.They can go to their Profile, into Calendar section and connect their Google calendar seamlesslyOnce the Google Authentication is done, the associate will start seeing all the Google Meetings that have at least one external meeting participant.The Associate can then see all the Google meetings for the day on the dashboard. The participants, will automatically be identified as Leads/Customers or internal participants.The Google Meeting can directly be joined from the Associate Dashboard.Developers: Jagdev

We have a Productivity Report that is currently consumed by Managers. This report tells you how many conversations your agents have made and the total duration of all the conversations for each agent. The table below the chart also provides you handling time, pitch score and agent talk ratio for each agent. You can now filter this data by date, team, type of call, type of conversation, pipelines and a particular signal. For example, Filtering by a particular signal like “Price objection” lets you look at the total number of conversations where a price objection was raised by a customer. Developers: Kartik

This documentation gives an overview of the infrastructure deployed on the AWS cloud. It lists out the component used along with security implications.
Our resources are deployed in the following regions:
The following components are used in the deployment:
The table gives an overview of the current status related to Application Security and industry stand compliances:
Amazon Elastic Kubernetes Service (Amazon EKS) runs the Kubernetes management infrastructure for you across multiple AWS Availability Zones to eliminate a single point of failure.
A highly available architecture that spans two Availability Zones.
A virtual private cloud (VPC) configured with public and private subnets according to AWS best practices
In the public subnets, managed NAT gateways is configured to allow outbound internet access for resources in the private subnets.

In one public subnet, a Linux bastion host in an Auto Scaling group to allow inbound Secure Shell (SSH) access to Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud (Amazon EC2) instances in private subnets. The bastion host is also configured with the Kubernetes kubectl command-line interface for managing the Kubernetes cluster.
An Amazon EKS cluster, which provides the Kubernetes control plane.
In the private subnets, a group of Kubernetes nodes which is hosting different services required for the application.
5. Application -  Components and their interaction

For the implementation of infrastructure, we are using the following tools:

We are using Terraform for implementing the infrastructure as code. For this purpose, we have created modules required for creating networking, routers, gateways, and the Kubernetes cluster along with the worker nodes. We are using Terraform version 1.1.6 and this has been deployed using Jenkins as a pipeline.

Jenkins has been hosted on our cloud servers which are used for creating pipelines. Using these pipelines, the cloud infrastructure is created first and later different components of the applications are deployed on the Kubernetes cluster.

Sonarqube is being used to perform static code analysis and create reports that aid in finding out the vulnerabilities and also mitigating them. We have hosted our Sonarqube server on the cloud and have been running over our different code repositories.
<< More to be added about Sonarqube version and other dependencies used for it>>

The goal of Apache Kafka is to solve the scaling and reliability issues that hold older messaging queues back. In Salesken we use Kafka as a Pub-Sub mechanism where Comm Produces Tasks in Kafka and CDR picks up tasks from Kafka on a regular interval which is then utilized by the Analysis Engine.

Redis is an open-source, in-memory data structure store, used as a database, cache, and message broker. In Salesken Redis is being used for persisting user & Organisation details as a cache to make frequently accessed data in memory so that applications can be responsive to users.

Elasticsearch allows us to store, search, and analyze huge volumes of data quickly and in near real-time and give back answers in milliseconds. It's able to achieve fast search responses because instead of searching the text directly, it searches an index. In Salesken Elasticsearch is used widely in storing analysis data and showing it to users in a fraction of a second.

Empathy is one of the most important skills for a sales rep to be successful.

Often confused with sympathy, empathy actually requires perspective-taking. When you are being empathetic, you are doing more than feeling sorry for another person; you are actually trying to imagine the situation from that person's point of view.
There are three different types of empathy, and it's possible to have more than one type at a time:
Emotional empathy - When you feel something because someone else does, this is emotional empathy. You may have noticed this when you cried watching a very sad scene in a movie.

Cognitive empathy - Involving thinking more than feeling, cognitive empathy means putting yourself in someone else's shoes. When you talk to a friend about something that is bothering you and feel understood by that person, it's often because your friend was using cognitive empathy.
Compassionate empathy - This is any kind of empathy that leads to action. When you see someone in need and offer that person some food or money, that is compassionate empathy.

Sign in to your Plecto’s account with username and password.
Go to the data source tab and click on the “+ New data source” button.
Select “Plecto API” data source from “others” category.
Enter required details such as title, label field and data retention period.
Click on “Fields” and add all the fields (example total calls, duration etc.) which you want show in the dashboard as KPI. The list fields are necessary to send correct API requests.
data_source : Select the Plecto api data source which you created. Note down the data source uuid from the URL as shown in below picture.
member_uuid : Select any admin employee from employee section and note down the member uuid from the URL as shown in the picture below.
Fields list : All the fields which are added in the Plecto api data source.
Username & password : Provide username and password of your employee signed in Plecto (preferably with admin privileges)

Authentication: The authentication scheme used for the Plecto API is Basic Authentication. This authentication scheme includes sending your username (email) and password along with the request. The employee must have admin access to succeed with most API endpoints.
Required Parameters: There are mandatory keys that must be included in the request body for every request that you send. They are the following: data_source, member, and external_id.
The data_source key requires the unique UUID of a data source. This alphanumeric string can be found in the URL when you open a data source.
member_api_provider refers to the name of your system. In the image below, the displayed system name is "Postman."

member_api_id refers to the member ID of your system. In Plecto, it is displayed under the "External ID" field because the member ID comes from an external system, meaning - yours. The member_api_provider and member_api_id together identify an employee in Plecto.

member_name is the name of the member. This name will be displayed in the "Employee" field in your Plecto data source and can be updated, provided that you use the same member_api_provider and member_api_id values.
OR

member uuid: member uuid requires to have an existing employee profile in Plecto. The member UUID can be found in the URL of an employee page. Go to Organization > Employees and click on the employee name to open their employee page and see the UUID.

The external_id is a number or a string of characters that has to be unique for each registration. It could be something like 123, abc or anything you can think of. This is important as it will be the reference of the created registration. The external ID values in your request body are displayed in the "ID" field in your Plecto data source (see the image below).
If you send a request with the same external ID as you have already used, it will overwrite an existing registration in Plecto and display the new updated information.

Freshsales CRM integration is a bidirectional data syncing process i.e. data insert and update from salesken to freshsales CRM and vice-versa. In this process basically, we are creating and updating tasks at freshsales CRM and pulling data like the user, lead, task, etc. from freshsales to salesken.

Step 1: We provide an integration page to integrate your client’s CRM to Salesken. On the integration page organization needs to fill in the credentials like client id, client secrete, base URL etc. and submit these details. On submit we authorize the credentials and store them into salesken database then we provide access to pull and push data through salesken.

Step 2: After authorization, we will provide mapping functionality where the admin can map the Salesken field to the CRM field and this data is stored in org_crm_mapping table salesken DB and if required create custom fields.

Step 3: Call through salesken dialer once call initiate that time task has been created into the Salesken DB. Take task id and hit the crm_integration API, here before the task creation at CRM we will sync user's or lead's details i.e. if user id or lead id present at CRM then fetch user id or lead id from CRM and update into the salesken DB. After syncing user/lead,  we will check CRM task id is present in the integration_metadata table or not. if present then update that task otherwise create a new entry in the table.
Note: we are extracting both user and lead from single API.

Open port 9092 for Kafka to listen on:vi /usr/local/etc/kafka/server.properties

Create Kafka topics:salesken@ronak-shah kafka % kafka-topics --create --topic test-topic --bootstrap-server localhost:9092 --replication-factor 1 --partitions 4 Created topic test-topic.Create Kafka Producer Messages:salesken@ronak-shah ~ % kafka-console-producer --broker-list localhost:9092 --topic test-topic
Create Kafka Consumer for test-topic Producer:salesken@ronak-shah kafka % kafka-console-consumer --bootstrap-server localhost:9092 --topic test-topic --from-beginning

If all is configured correctly, you should see “test local first message”, “test local second message” as soon as Consumer for your topic test-topic is initiated via localhost port 9092. This implies, your local kafka is now ready to act as message broker queue.

Salesken offers the SMS feature which is quick, time-saving and results can be analyzed quickly. This is systematic, simple to set up, and has an instantaneous impact on responses and sales opportunities.
Admin can set multiple caller ids for an associate. Your outbound caller ID is the phone number or name that people see displayed when you call them.
When the associate sends a message to the Lead/customer, it is considered as an outbound SMS.
Templates make it easier for you to respond to frequently asked questions and send out mass texts.
All the templates are designed by the admin of the organization.
Whenever SMS is received on an agent's number from a lead then it is known as inbound SMS.
Send / receive SMS
(Countries)
This section of the report captures the objections raised by the customers to whom the associate reached out during this date range.
If the customer is objecting that the price is too expensive then It’s too expensive will be the trigger word for the objection signal..
Breakdown by sales Representative  means all details are shown according to the associate which contains the name of associate, No. of calls made by associate and signal which is caught  during call.
This shows the overall view of the total objections caught in the form of a pie chart.
We can get idea about all the objection caught as a signal and even the trigger words used.
We can get the idea about a particular objection and get the details about the different trigger words used in that particular objection.

This report gives an overall analysis of the quantity and quality of sales conversations.        Conversation metrics reports allow you to select and highlight key discussions to examine and improve the quality and performance.
Duration Reports are a collection of calls made by the agent that allow you to analyze the performance of your team and business.
A heatmap chart is the 2-D visual representation of data, where values are encoded in colors, providing a convenient and insightful view of data.
Number of conversations with duration smaller than 3 minute
Number of conversations having duration greater than and equal to 3 minutes and smaller than 6 minutes.
Number of conversations having duration greater than and equal to 6 minute and smaller than 9 minutes
number of conversation having duration greater than and equal to 9 minutes
Call connects reports has the information of the total number of calls , numbers of conversation connects , number of meaningful connects , number of quality connects per associate.
Number of conversations with duration greater than 45 seconds ( duration > 45sec)

Duration Reports by time contains the information about total number of Conversations, short conversations , good length conversations , above normal conversations and long conversations done in that specified time range (interval of 2 hours) irrespective of the date.

Userwise Duration Reports by time contains the information about the number of conversations made by a particular associate in that specified time range (interval of 2 hours) irrespective of the date.
Displays the time range interval for every 2 hours in 24 hours irrespective of date

Call Connects by time reports basically has the information of the total number of calls , numbers of conversation connects , number of meaningful connects , number of quality connects done in that specified time range (interval of 2 hours) irrespective of the date.
Userwise Call Connects by time reports basically has the information about the total number of calls made by the users in the specified time range (interval of 2 hours) irrespective of the date.
Cue Adherence means incorporating risk in the reward formulation in the random case when an agent deviates from the desired cue type. This gives rise to uncertainty aware reinforcement learning.

It shows information regarding Cue details,Cue detected and Cue adhered. Breakdown by cues means it contains the details of cues like My child is very young,will do after 2-3 years. I think now is not the right time for these classes.It also shows the details of the number of times the cues are detected and cues adhered.
It shows information of Users name,Cue detected and Cue adhered.Breakdown by sales representative tab contains users name in the left side while cue detected and cue adhered in the right side.

There are certain organization level settings, that control the behaviour of users operating and interacting with the platform. Below are further details:

Any individual logged in with Associate role from the organization downloading any reports from any  Reporting page will not receive columns containing Customer Personal Information (Phone Number, Email id)
Any Manager logged in with Manager role in the organization downloading any reports from any  Reporting page will not receive columns containing Customer Personal Information (Phone Number, Email id)

Any Manager logged in with Associate role in the organization trying to use any page on the Salesken portal, will see all fields containing Customer Personal Information (Phone Number, Email id) masked in format ‘xxxx-xxxx-xxxx’

Any Associate logged in with Associate role in the organization trying to use any page on the Salesken portal, will see all fields containing Customer Personal Information (Phone Number, Email id) masked in format ‘xxxx-xxxx-xxxx’

Any Associate logged in with Associate role in the organization trying to make a call, will see the Record option as disabled by default and will not have an ability to toggle the Recording to Active state.

We’re so glad to have you join the team! This guide is meant to provide team-specific information to help you get off to a great and productive start.

Salesken helps companies realize the benefits of the “Science of Sales”. We’re a group of technologists and training professionals who’ve come together to bring the best of AI and Data Sciences to sales performance!

Salesken gives companies incredible insights into the last mile of customer-salesperson interactions.  The sales team can communicates with customers on calls, presentations and webinars and get insights into what they are doing right, and where they need help. SalesKen also lets sales team improve with customized learning content to help them up their game and win!
Our mission is to help build sales team where every salesperson is a top achiever

Mapping of Just Call Entity and Salesken Call Entity

Just Call is a dialer where we can make or receive calls. Just Call will store the details of the calls. A Scheduler will be invoked every 30 minutes. Using API we will fetch call details of given time limits/range. Then it will send the call details as a response to the user.
Using API we will fetch the call details from the Just Call of a given time range. Just Call will send call details as a string or object as a response.
This API accepts the following parameters which let me fetch the latest calls which have been placed in the last 10 minutes.
With this base, we try to schedule a cron job on google cloud scheduler. The scheduler calls the API every 10 minutes and fetches the calls which were placed during that time.
Just Call provides stats API so that we can get the Just Call Object and the details of the calls of a certain period.Request Response:​https://justcall.io/developer-docs/#calls

After calling API to retrieve the call details from dialer, the dialer will send all call details as a response. Call Transformer is used to transform the call details we get from the 8x8 dialer API into the Salesken Call Objects.
The just call  stats API gives us the just call object with the following fields, we then create a just call response entity with the fields.
Mapping of Just Call Entity and Salesken Call Object:
The fields from the Just Call response entity are mapped into the Salesken call object as follows:-
A brief explanation of all the entities involved in this feature and a diagram.
The very first step towards Just Call is to SignUp into it.
After logging in with Google we have to make an account in Just Call.
After successful Just Call Pro or Enterprise account creation, we are all set to use it.
To make a REST API call, we must include request headers including the Authorization headers with your API Key and API Secret.
To get the API Key and API Secret we have to select “Settings”. Then click on “Developers”, it will redirect us to the required API Key and API Secret.
These API Key and API Secret is used to make a REST API call.
The combination of API Key and API Secret ,separated by a:(colon) is required as Authorization header.
A schedular calls an API endpoint which triggers the process for the CDR JustCall.
The CDRs are being fetched from JustCall and transformed to PullCall object which is then dumped to elastic search index.

Simultaneously, the callSid and ordId are being sent to the kafka producer, from where then the data is being consumed by a consumer and the data from the consumer is then being used to make tasks in the salesken DB.

This POC was done to study the behavior of the Freshsales CRM to test the APIs and other CRM related functionality.
This POC is divided into three parts:
Firstly, we will signup and create a trial account into the Freshsales CRM.
Secondly, we will create contact and add task for the newly made contact.
Thirdly, we will test the API available in the developers section of Freshsales API collection for CRM.
Part : I Signup and Creation of trial account
Step 1: Move to Freshsales signup page and create an account. The mail id that is going to be used for signup should be one having organization name in the domain name.
Step 2: After signing up we will be redirected to the dashboard page of the Freshsales CRM.
Step 3: After the successful signing up to the CRM dashboard, next step is to obtain the API token for using the APIs available in the Developer Section.
II : Creation of Contact and Creation of Task

Step 5 : Now after the contact is created we can create task for the newly created contact, we can also create task for the sample available contact. For creating task we can click on the three dots available for editing the  contact, which will open up a dropdown and we need to select add task.
III Fetching the list of task using the API
Step 1. For fetching the list of tasks, first we can go to the API library and then navigate to the list all tasks API. We can use the curl code and test the API.

Step 2: For running the curl code we need to change the token with our API key and we need to replace the domain name with our organization’s domain name. We can also use different filters available in the documentation of the API
Step 3: On testing the curl code on Postman, we get the newly added task in response.
