In the current scenario, we are passing all secrets during Build time, which is not feasible as the build will be created and used only for a single purpose. What if we pass secrets at run time so that a single build can be used multiple times with different variables.
Currently, we are managing secrets in GitHub Repositories, That is vulnerable as secrets will be shared with everyone who has access to the GitHub repository.

Put All Secrets in Environment, so that whenever an application is deployed the particular app will get secrets from the respective Environment.                                                                                                                                           Eg. String environmentVariable = System.getEnv("environment_variable_name");
Put all secrets in AWS secret Manager and get secrets from there.
If Load running on AWS only then It will be very useful else the data needs to be traveled from one to another Environment.
Problems with rate limits, although that is a problem more generally with AWS.
There is a cost associated with each secret stored in AWS.
We will use some specific Variable Names for this, For Eg.
Here we will add Properties that are common across all applications, If Properties which are not vulnerable and we can pass through ENV variables or we can put them in the GitHub repo only.

Virtual Audio Cable is a software product based on WDM multimedia driver that allows a user to transfer audio streams from one application to another. Any application is able to send an audio stream to the input side of a "virtual cable" while a corresponding application can receive this stream from the output side. Since all transfers are made digitally, there is no loss in sound quality
So after installing the VAC Windows application, we were able to stream the audio from an mp3 file to a client (Audio Repeater )

But in order to send the stream to cueing server , we need to convert the stream into raw PCM (bytes) so that we can send it to the cueing service , just like whttps://github.com/dynopii/pyvirtualaudiocablee are doing in case of Twilio Calls.
Since we don’t have any way to customize the Windows App, we are looking towards an open source alternative to this (i.e. ​https://github.com/dynopii/pyvirtualaudiocable )
Developer has to  own the quality of code they write .Here are few steps to improve  overall quality of our code base
We need to be  clear on  the requirements  and HLD/LLD design before start writing code .We need to document it at respective places wherever possible .
Does code do what it intends to do as per requirement.
Code should be modular and easy to read .
Proper commenting at necessary places Ex . While defining new class/function /design
Code should follow the best practises in coding style for respective language.
Code should be written in a way that it can be tested properly for various cases both manual and  automated .
Below  testing has to be done at developer stage. Test cases has to be included wherever possible
The  purpose of code review is to make sure that the overall code health improves, minimise bugs and coach  developers on  Language, framework, or general software design principles
Comment can  be  both  educational and critical

In any conflict on a code review, the first step should always be for the developer and reviewer to try to come to consensus.If it don't work set up face to face meeting. Next stage will be to escalate for broader team discussion.
Comments on what and why(if relevant) you are doing . Must before defining new class/function /design .

The first step while assessing the code quality of the entire project is through a static code analysis tool. Use the tools (based on technology) such as SonarQube, NDepend, FxCop, TFS code analysis rules. There is a myth that static code analysis tools are only for managers..
To track the code review comments use the tools like Crucible, Bitbucket and TFS code review process.

Here Master Branch will be running on Production.
Suppose we are developing a Feature “Feature A“, So developers will create a branch “feature_a“ & start working on it and when it get compeleted the code will be merged to “dev” branch.
Merging to “dev“ branch will trigger a pipeline & it will be deployed to dev environment.
After testing on dev environment, the respective code will be merged to “qa” branch by raising a pull request.
Merging to qa branch will deploy code to respective qa environment and QA will start testing on it.
If there is some bug fixes then the same process repeates as feature_a branch will still be there.
After QA Approval the code will be merged to master branch and the code gets deployed to Production environment after a Pull request.
Now we can delete feature_a branch if needed.
Suppose there is a bug on Production and needs to be fix ASAP.
After the compeletion of the same the code will be merged to master branch after a pull request.

Issue reported in Prod  → QA will analyze the issue with support team → Replicate the issue in QA env → Provide/Add all the detailed description in Issue → Assigned to Anurag → Anurag’s team will fix the issue → Assigned to QA for the validation → QA will verify the FIX → QA will give sign off to Support for the deployment → Email to all internal stakeholders regarding new features/changes/issue fixed→ Support/Delivery team will deploy the changes in PROD.

New Requirement by customer → CS will move requirements to Stockholders  → Stockholders will finalize the feature → Assigned to Dev team → Dev team will deliver the feature to QA → QA will test the feature → QA will give sign off to Support for the deployment → Email to all internal stakeholders regarding new features/changes/issue fixed → Support/Delivery team will deploy the changes in PROD.

Internal support Requirement  → Stockholders will finalize the feature → Assigned to Dev team → Dev team will deliver the feature to QA → QA will test the feature → QA will give sign off to Support for the deployment → Email to all internal stakeholders regarding new features/changes/issue fixed Support/Delivery team will deploy the changes in PROD.

Purpose : To fetch data from redis instead of database.
Assumption:  Data  fetched from redis will be faster as compared to data fetched from database.

Overview:  An  API  is created that will fetch data from redis first,if the data is null then the data will be fetched from the database and it will be inserted into redis. It takes very less time to fetch and update data from redis as compared to databases.

When a user will send the request to fetch data ,then first backend will check if the data is present in redis or not , if the data is present in redis  then the data will be returned to the backend and the same data will be returned to the user too and if the data is not present in redis then it will return “null” and backend will fetch data from Database  and the same data will be added to redis and  will be returned to the user too.
If a user try to update any data present in the database it should be updated in redis and in the database as well.

"profile": "The X Factor is a television music competition franchise created by British producer Simon Cowell and his company SYCOtv. It originated in the United Kingdom, where it was devised as a replacement for Pop Idol (2001–2003), and has been adapted in various countries. The \"X Factor\" of the title refers to the undefinable \"something\" that makes for star quality.[1] The prize is usually a recording contract, in addition to the publicity that appearance in the later stages of the show itself generates, not only for the winner but also for other highly ranked contestants. Unlike Idols, where the judges only critique the contestants performances, on The X Factor each judge \"mentors\" the finalists in a particular category, aiding them with song selection and styling, while also participating together in judging the contestants in the other categories. Not only Idols, but also new singing shows such as The Voice and All Together Now have become rivals and popular in recent years.",

In 2.0.3 , we have made changes in cueing , user management , superadmin and  reporting. Their impacts are mentioned below as discussed in the Impact analysis meet on 29th November 2021 at 1:00 PM .

Our cueing project is not as stable as of now. Apparently , the issue is that after creating threads on the server , our cueing engine is not destroying those threads , which is leading to bottleneck in system resources.

Due to this we need to rewrite some of the code to fix the aforementioned problem, we’ll probably need to break cueing service in 2 parts , 1st will receive the snippet , and the other will send cues. Other issues include:
Lack of testing for cueing as it is not reliably stable

Lack of monitoring for cues based on call Ids. We are storing cue and FAQ data in Kibana, but there is yet to be an official UI for that so the Support Team can also see what transcription and corresponding cues have been generated for any particular Call.
We don’t see the cue count in the task list anywhere in our App
We don’t have a cue adherence report that could specify how well the agent has followed the cues shown
ICICI Bank is a big customer , which is planned to go live by January 2022 , will use cueing as our main feature and we haven’t included a cueing revamp in 2.0.4 as well.
Will also need to link the cue count report with cues UI
We currently don’t have cueing for Conference Calls , which also needs to be added for Bulldog.
The user management feature on Superadmin had been completely moved to the Backend Project.
Need to add cue count in task list.
Need to add transcription report and cues report for each call.

We have changed the Calling UI , as we have migrated the dialer from Model to the Page itself. This will be new for customers and has not been tested on a large scale, or even for a single customer yet.
We have now provided a default Disposition page after each call. Here the issue is that some customers like White Hat Junior , won’t need it.

We didn’t do anything for conference call  this sprint, and that is an urgent requirement from Bulldog. So now it will probably be done on the fly without any documentation and proper JIRA task , which could be a failure in sprint planning.
We have changed the source of associate reports , so now instead of PostgreSQL ,the reports are coming from Elasticsearch. This could lead to inconsistency in  data and functionality like :
There could be a data mismatch between Manager / Superadmin and Associate Reports as the data source of  Manager and Superadmin is still PostgreSQL.
Snippet search works on Associate report , but not in Manager reports
Some extremely important things that we can do to increase the performance and quality of our release are :
We can integrate with Auth0 again , so that session data is not hampered when we do deployment during production hours in order to provide hotfixes.
Reanalyze button which was developed back in 2.0.2 is not integrated in this release. We need to plan adding it to our next sprint

We need to create and alternative to Comm, which will fix the call log issues we are facing in production, these are likely to be fixed in release 2.0.4 as we are rewriting the CDR import project for Twilio and Plivo
Our Cloud ASR Engine won’t work in ICICI , so we need to plan that as well.

Unlike lead qualification, it is sufficient if the sales rep discovers atleast one or some of the needs of the client.

Correct need identification helps sales reps correctly map the right product out of a bouquet of products/ product features out of a set of features / solutioning for the right need.  In advanced versions of the product, we will build a feature need mapping and propose to have product recommendations for the right need, once the data science on need discovery model is more accurate. Feature to need mapping could be a many to many model, and the focus should be on ordering needs and applicable feature sets in a priority.

Need discovery calls also have an additional dimension of time.  Understanding customers need or pain point early on in a sales call is a critical factor in closing sales.  Asking good discovery questions early on in the call helps sales reps contextualise the solution with respect to the customers problems/ requirements.
Sub Signals : Need discovery questions are linked to either
Customer pain point - too much manual intervention (solution is saas), lack of personal attention (1:1 tutoring), managing risk (mutual funds), vulnerability (insurance),
In edtech, “Does your child get personal attention in class?” “Does your child follow everything in the classroom?”
In insurance, “Are you the only earning member in your family?”
Some other examples of generic examples of need discovery questions:
What is your boss or team hoping to accomplish in the next year?
How do your team’s objectives play into your department's strategy?
What do you perceive as your team’s greatest strength? Weakness?
From your perspective, what do you perceive your needs to be? How important are they?
How does your company evaluate the potential of new products or services?
Who has your business now? Why did you choose that vendor?
What are your buying criteria and success criteria?
Where would you put the emphasis regarding price, quality, and service?
What level of service are you looking for?
What do you like best about your present supplier? What don't you like?
What do you look for in the companies you do business with?
What do you like best about your current system? What would you like to see changed?
Would you rather cut costs, save money, or increase productivity?

It is important for the sales rep to be exhaustive in the qualification.

Typically, industry best practices around lead qualification follow practises such as BANT (Budget, Authority, Needs, Timeline), CHAMP (Challenges, Authority, Money, Priority), MEDDIC (Metrics (RoI), Economic Buyer, Decision Criteria, Decision Process, Pain Point Identification, Champion).

For Salesken, we do not include these elements under Lead Qualification as each of those criteria are being evaluated independently under separate heads with separate business and data science logic.   For Salesken, we define Lead Qualification primarily around:
In insurance, classic qualifying questions are around premium determination - Are you a smoker? How old are you?
In Saas, for salesken, qualifying questions are “Do you use a CRM? Which CRM do you use currently? Which dialer do you use currently?'
For Edtech, qualifying questions could be “What grade is your child in? Does your child go to tuitions currently?”
For logistics, lead qualification could be “How many bedrooms are in your current house? Could you list the things you wish to move? What is the location of the places you’d wish to move?”
For home interior design, lead qualification could be “Is this your first house or second home?” “Is this an investment home?”
For construction, lead qualification could be “Whats the size of the pool? What materials are currently being used?”
Do you qualifiy your lead on the calls?

Connections are the crux of human bonding.  Its a moment of zing…when there is a shared emotion - joy, laughter, pain, understanding. Human beings long for lasting connections.  This is the crux and the starting point of any good sales interaction.  Rapport building is core to establish a “common point” and “connect” outside of the sales conversation.  It is ideally done before the sales pitch begins but can be done during the call as well.  Rapport building in salesken is defined in a personal context 1:1 with the buyer, outside of the sales script.
Rapport building can happen over anything outside of the sales pitch.  A few common rapport building areas:
A rule for rapport building is to not get over friendly or over personal.

What's going on in your business these days?
Do you have any exciting plans for the weekend (last weekend, coming up, and so forth)?

Skilled sales reps create a sense of urgency in potential customers. Without a deadline or time limit for buying your product or service, prospects will often spend time evaluating its pros and cons without making a decision and the sale can be stuck in a limbo.  A limbo is the true death knell of a prospect.  Death of a sales lead is rarely with a bang, mostly in quiet unresponsive whimpers.  A lead open for long can bring up competitor’s, bad reviews etc. An emotion of desire or need created in a sales call has a life…that emotion starts to fade with time and it is a crucial component of a sales process to create urgency to a purchase decision.

Fear - scarcity ie FOMO.  The fear of missing out (FOMO) is a highly effective technique to create a big sense of urgency. By telling the prospect how many products are left in stock at this moment, or how many spots are left at your exclusive event, you can use FOMO to your advantage.
20% discount on the price or a bonus when they buy within the next two hours
Only so many products are left in stock

One of the core problems with most sales reps is the rush to start talking about product features.  Sales could be sold on

At Salesken, we have found that a sales pitch based on the product and its features, without emphasis on the buyers needs is a recipe for failure.  A sales pitch largely focused on the product does not connect to the customer.  The reason why  large number of sales reps rely on the less sophisticated product selling is:

Such methods of engagement do not create sufficient buyer engagement as the customer becomes passive in the conversation, rarely talking only listening.  There is a strong correlation between buyer engagement, buyer conversation/ responses/ talk time and sales stickiness.  To improve buyer engagement and resonance with the conversation, consultative selling has emerged as the better, more sophisticated way of selling.

It is important to engage the customer in his context.  Consultative selling is a great way to engage the customers.  Control over the conversation is harder to achieve in the conversational method of selling.  However, it has the great benefit of buyer engagement and buyer relaying his business/ need context.  The chemistry of the conversations can be built upon a lot more in a typical fashion as below:
Reference other pain/ need contexts for other similar buyers
Sell the problem back to the buyer and become the “knowledge expert of the problem”
Once buyer and rep are on the same “problem club”, become the knowledge expert of the solution - a new and amazing clever way to solve the problem
Shift gears from “sales person looking at the buyer as a wallet” to “knowledge leader who is seeking to help and enable success for the buyer”
Sell the product features as a solution to the buyers problem
Use buyer context (gained during need discovery) repeatedly during the product explanation
Talk pricing - by the time the pricing discussion is had, buyer and rep need to be completely on same page for the problem and the solution
Find out buyer’s organisational/ personal goals (need discovery 2)
Find out decision making process for the purchase decision (need discovery 3)

Change buyer into the champion (paint the vision for how buyer championing will provide strong organisation wins and help the buyer achieve goals, if b2b, else focus on buyers goals being acheived with purchase of the solution.  Sell the buyers goals back to him/her.)
Agree on next steps to engage other decision makers, if there are any.
Check rep question intensity: how many questions are being asked by the rep per call.  Who/where/what/how/for whom etc

A good closing is important as it connects the dots between sales calls.  A sales rep may cover all other dimensions of the playbook well, but if he forgets the closing aspects of the playbook, the lead has high potential to die.  The goal of a good closing is to ensure that next steps for the call are clearly defined and the call ends on a positive note.

A good opening sets the stage for the sales call.  For sales calls, time is a crucial dimension as there is a finite amount of time to make an impression on the customer and the words spoken early make a significant impact in how the customer perceives the experience.  Credentialing, positivity and high energy are the most important traits of a good opening.

Opening is best calculated only for first meaningful calls.  So tag all calls as first calls or follow up calls. Do not include follow up calls in opening calculations as the sales rep may not repeat all aspects of credentialing during follow up calls and is likely to only introduce himself second time over in brief
Sub-signals : Typical opening sub signals are
I am <name>, <designation such as Academic Counsellor/ relationship manager/ designer>
I am calling from the Relationship banking department
For your information, this call is being recorded
Do you want to check the lead source for the customer?
You had enquired on our website and left your contact details
Facebook, linkedin, social media, google, friend etc
Data collection for opening will be done during the onboarding wizard/ questionnaire
X% of your calls had a great opening.
Text: A great opening sets the right tone for a sales call.  100-X% of your calls did not greet the customer sufficiently or credential themselves or the organization well.
If coverage is over 90%, mark call as “Good opening”, else mark call as “Incomplete opening”.
Calculate coverage % for each subsignal as high medium low
High can be >50%, medium is 25-50%, low is less than 25% coverage for a signal
Greeting % =  No of meaningful first calls where Greeting subsignal was present / Total No of meaningful calls
Self Credentialing = No of meaningful first calls where Self credentialing subsignal was present / Total No of meaningful calls
Company Credentialing = No of meaningful first calls where Company credentialing subsignal was present / Total No of meaningful calls
Lead source = No of meaningful first calls where lead source subsignal was present / Total No of meaningful calls

Media service will polls Media queue after the process will send the data to Master service

Aircall is a dialer where we can make or receive calls. Aircall will store the details of the calls. A Scheduler will be invoked for every 30 minutes. Using API we will fetch call details of given time limits/range. Then it will send the call details as a response to the user.

The first scenario is the Basic Authorization. In this scenario, the user will select Aircall Dialer from the Sales Manager Web Application. After selection of Aircall dialer a window will open, where the user will enter the credentials like api_id and api_token. After getting details api_id and api_token will be concatenated with : and then resulted string is encoded using Base64. Then we will send a request to the Aircall for Authorization using encoded string using below format. After successful authorization entry gets created in cdr_provider table. And also set is_active status to true in cdr_provider table.
Request : https://api.aircall.io/v1/ping \ -H "Authorization: Basic {YOUR_ENCODED_STRING}"

In this scenario a Scheduler will be invoked for every 30 minutes. Then using API we will fetch the call details from the Aircall of a given time range. Aircall will send a call details as a string or object as a response.

Cron job is created on google scheduler. There will be two task, one is for creating cloud task and another one is to delete a cloud task. Scheduler will invoke for every 30 minutes. Based on this we will schedule a cron job on google cloud scheduler. The scheduler will call for an API to retrieve the   call details from the dialer with some time range/limit. Then dialer will fetch all call details of given time range. Then it will send all call details as a response.

After calling API to retrieve the call details from dialer, dialer will send all call details as response. Call Transformer is used to transforms the call details we get from the Aircall dialer API into the Salesken Call Objects. The sample schema for the Salesken Call object is given below.
Mapping of Aircall Entity and Salesken Call Object
The fields from the Aircall response entity are mapped into the Salesken call object as follows:-
Media server is used for converting a call recording file to WAV file. After converting it will returns the wav file and also it will be uploaded to Google Cloud bucket.

If user doesn’t want to use Aircall as a dialer then he can uninstall the Aircall dialer from Sales Manager Web Application by clicking on Aircall dialer and uninstall it. After uninstallation cdr_provider table will be updated as Aircall is_active status set to false. After successful uninstallation all cloud task related to Aircall dialer should be deleted.

When the user selects Aircall dialer from the  Sales Manager Web Application, he will provide us the credentials i.e api_id and api_token. After getting the details api_id and api_token is concatenated using : and then resulted string will be encoded using base64. Then using this encoded string we will send a request for authorization. If data gets stored successfully API response will be HTTP 200 else it will throw an exception.

Once a call is made by the agent or the user the call details will be stored in Aircall. Then there will be one scheduler that invokes for every 30 minutes. Then using api we will send a request to retrieve all call details of a given time range/limit. Then Aircall will retrieve all call details and send it as a response. Then that call details will be stored into the Salesken DB.

Once we get call recording then we have convert a audio file into WAV file. We will convert audio file into wav file using media server. Once we get audio file then we have to send a request to a media server. Then media server will convert the audio file to wav file and returns the audio file. And also audio will uploaded to Google cloud bucket. In the request we will send the method, url, uuid, bucketName and webhookUrl. In the url we will send the audio file link which is to be converted into WAV file. In uuid field we will send the callid. In the request we will also provide the bucket name of the Google cloud where the task will be stored. webhookUrl is used to update the call object after audio file is converted.

Here is the approach document for Salesken + Salesforce Integration for Oct-Nov 2021:
Select icon of Salesforce crm on salesken application
Users put the credentials of Salesforce for login.
Once we get the access token we just save and update it into the crm_integration table.
For authentication we hit Salesforce access token api.
Make a GET request to the URL below to get the Access Code.
After running this URL, you will be redirected to a redirect url with  an auth code appended in the url. Copy auth code from the redirect url and create a new URL as shown below.
Make a POST request with this url. This will give access token, refresh token and instance url.
Instance URL will be used at the start of every url used to make requests to api.
Make a POST request for refreshing the access token.
After successful authentication and authorization, we can query the Salesforce CRM for required objects. Add Authorization Header as Bearer access_token in all the requests.
Get a list of all the salesforce objects
Identify the fields which contain the relevant CDR data and write SOQL (Salesforce Object Query Language) to fetch it.
Fetch access_token from crm_integration schema based on company_id.
Validate access_token. If it is expired renew for the new access_token with the help of refresh_token.
In the service layer our service will hit the Salesforce search api to get the lead details whose email is same as the email we get in DTO.

After getting lead details and corresponding to the lead details our service will hit the Salesforce contact api based on lead_id for getting association of leads and deals where our lead is similar to contact of Salesforce.
Our service will hit the Salesforce deal api for deal details for each deal on the basic of deal_id and applying some filter.
At last we map the response we get form Salesforce to the SearchLeadResponse .

RingCentral is a dialer where we can make or receive calls and RingCentral stores all the call details made from his platform. We will fetch the call details using the RingCentral API which will invoke every 30 minutes and store the call details in the Salesken database.

In this scenario, a Scheduler will be invoked every 30 minutes. Then using API we will fetch the call details from the RingCentral of a given time range. RingCentral will send call details as a string or object as a response.

Cron Job is created on google scheduler. There will be two tasks, one is for creating a cloud task and another one is to delete a cloud task. The scheduler will invoke for every 30 minutes. Based on this we will schedule a Cron  Job on google cloud scheduler. The scheduler will call for an API to retrieve the call details from the dialer with some time range/limit. Then dialer will fetch all call details of the given time range.

Once a call is made by the agent or the user the call details will be stored in RingCentral. Then there will be one scheduler that invokes for every 30 minutes. Then using API we will send a request to retrieve all call details of a given time range/limit. Then RingCentral will retrieve all call details and send them as a response. Then that call details will be stored in the Salesken DB.

Once we get call recording then we have to convert an audio file into a WAV file. We will convert an audio file into a WAV file using a media server. Once we get the audio file then we have to send a request to a media server. Then media server will convert the audio file to a WAV file and returns the audio file. And also audio will be uploaded to Google cloud bucket.

8X8 is a dialer where we can make or receive calls. 8X8 will store the details of the calls. A Scheduler will be invoked every 30 minutes. Using API we will fetch call details of given time limits/range. Then it will send the call details as a response to the user.

The first scenario is the Basic Authorization. In this scenario, the user will select 8X8 Dialer from the Sales Manager Web Application. After the selection of the 8X8 dialer, a window will open, where the user will enter the credentials like api_id and api_token. After getting details api_id and api_token will be concatenated with: and then resulted in the string is encoded using Base64. Then we will send a request to the 8x8 dialer for Authorization using encoded string using the below format. After successful authorization entry gets created in cdr_provider table.

In this scenario, a Scheduler will be invoked every 30 minutes. Then using API we will fetch the call details from the 8x8 of a given time range. 8x8 will send call details as a string or object as a response.

The cron job is created on google scheduler. There will be two tasks, one is for creating a cloud task and another one is to delete a cloud task. The scheduler will invoke for every 30 minutes. Based on this we will schedule a cron job on google cloud scheduler. The scheduler will call for an API to retrieve the call details from the dialer with some time range/limit. Then dialer will fetch all call details of the given time range. Then it will send all call details as a response.

After calling API to retrieve the call details from dialer, the dialer will send all call details as a response. Call Transformer is used to transform the call details we get from the 8x8 dialer API into the Salesken Call Objects. The sample schema for the Salesken Call object is given below.
The media server is used for converting a call recording file to a WAV file. After converting it will return the WAV file and also it will be uploaded to the Google Cloud bucket.

If the user doesn’t want to use 8x8 as a dialer then he can uninstall the 8x8 dialer from the Sales Manager Web Application by clicking on the 8x8 dialer and uninstalling it. After uninstallation cdr_provider table will be updated as 8x8 is_active status set to false. After successful uninstallation, all cloud tasks related to the 8x8 dialer should be deleted.

When the user selects the 8x8 dialer from the  Sales Manager Web Application, he will provide us the credentials i.e api_id and api_token. After getting the details api_id and api_token are concatenated using: and the resulted string will be encoded using base64. Then using this encoded string we will send a request for authorization. If data gets stored successfully API response will be HTTP 200 else it will throw an exception.

Once a call is made by the agent or the user the call details will be stored in 8x8. Then there will be one scheduler that invokes for every 30 minutes. Then using API we will send a request to retrieve all call details of a given time range/limit. Then 8x8 will retrieve all call details and send them as a response. Then that call details will be stored in the Salesken database.

This is the data flow diagram of this integration.
“Id”: String :-    This id will be the random id.
“request_body” : String   :-  The request body contains the data to be sent using the request_url to fetch        some details.
“request_url”: String   :- This request_url contains the api on which the data will be fetched or posted using GET or POST methods. This request_url contains the request_body as params.
“response_code”: String   :-   Response code contains the result of the request we have sent. The code will be one of these : (200,400,401,500).
“response_body”: String   :-  Response body contains the response code, response message and also some details about call details.
“company_id”: String  :-  This Company_id will be the id of the company (ex: aircall)
“created_at” : Date :- Creation date of the ELK index. It will be the system time.
“eventName” : String :- This field will contains event names such as cdrfetch, cdrtransform, mediahandling, usercheck, crmdealcheck, callcreated, playbook.
“cdrProviderId“ : String :- This field will contains id of the provider.
“exception_message” : String  :- This field will contain the exception message which is thrown during the process.
“exception_code” : String  :- This field will contain the exception code which is thrown during the process. Some exception codes are 401,400,500.
“call_uuid”: String  :-  This field will contain the caller id.
“call_started_time”: String :- This field will contain the starting time of the call or time when the call is started.
“call_ended_time”: String :- This field will contain the time of the call when it is ended.
“call_duration”: String :- This field will contain the total duration of the call.
“leg_1_number”: String  :- This field will contain the phone number of the agent.
“leg_2_number”: String  :-  This field will contain the phone number of the customer.
“user_email”: String   :- This field will contain the email address of the user.
“call_status”: String   :- This field will contain the status of the phone call. Some call_status are missed, transferred, answered, ended.
“Provider_name”: String  :- This field will contain the name of the Provider.

This report shows a summary of how, and which, Signals were marked collectively during all sales conversations. It consists of different sections mentioned below:

1 . Signals(Semantic/emotion): This section is a graph that shows the percentage of occurrence of each signal during all the sales conversations, This graph can be switched between showing semantic signals vs emotion signals by toggling the switch at the top right corner.
The ‘Signal Coverage Stats’ section shows the signal level statistics. It shows -
Instances - The number of times the signal was observed across all sales conversations.
progress - The percentage of the analyzed conversations where the signal appeared at least once.
Coverage - The percentage of increase or decrease in signal observed as compared to the previous week

The data entered is updated in the database using the below queries -
Configure the twiMl app’s request url - Needs to https and return xml to handle the call.
Token generation with Account SID, API Key and API secret
Account SID, API Key and API Secret are taken from company_config entries using the logged in user’s company id from the postgres database (staging -> salesken_v2_1).
Grant is basically a list of permission token grant’s to the user, it can be conversation, calling, sms, or video.
Token is built using twilio’ s helper library : AccessToken then converted to jwt format.

String acctSid = "YOUR ACCOUNT SID";String applicationSid = "YOUR APP SID";String apiKey = "API KEY";String apiSecret = "API SECRET KEY";// Create Voice grantVoiceGrant grant = new VoiceGrant();grant.setOutgoingApplicationSid(applicationSid);      // Optional: add to allow incoming callsgrant.setIncomingAllow(true);        // Create access tokenAccessToken accessToken = new AccessToken.Builder(acctSid, apiKey, apiSecret)                .identity(identity)                .grant(grant)                .build();
.identity(identity)
.grant(grant)
.build();
More Info on Twilio’s Access Token - ​https://www.twilio.com/docs/iam/access-tokens

A response xml is generated to tell the twilio.device. “CallerID” is basically from which the user receives the call. CallerID needs to be verified by twilio. “TO” is basically the number to which a call is made.
To record we need to pass a verb record in <Dail> in xml, which states which type of recording user wants to enable.
Currently we are using the “record-from-ringing-dual” option in <Dial> element which essentially allows dual channel recording from the moment ringing starts.
We can get several parameters from the twilio request object sent from Twilio server to our application-
“Caller” - We can get userId from this parameter by splitting based on : (colon).
“To” - We can get the dialed number from this parameter.
“CallSid” - We can get Twilio Call SID from this parameter which is used for making salesken_cdr entries in the postgres database (staging -> salesken_v2_1).
While making CDR entry to the database we are storing CallSid, provider, owner, client detail, call type and created time. If CallSid starts with “CA” then we store “Twilio” in the provider.
Once FE get’s token, Twilio.Device can be initiated.
To make an outgoing call Twilio.Device.Connect is called, providing an object with a phone number, taken by the user via an input.
The number entered  is validated using regex /^\+?[1-9]\d{11,14}$/
If the number is invalid, an error message is shown.
After connect is called, the request url defined in the twiMl app is hit by twilio which has an xml response and tells twilio what needs to be done.
After the call is initiated, events are provided by the twilio on Twilio Call instance to handle cases like :
Endpoint configured to xml app, which will have - username & password
Configure the xml app answer url - Needs to https and return xml to handle the call.
Plivo Endpoints - username and password are fetched from company_config entries using the logged in user’s company id from the postgres database (staging -> salesken_v2_1).
A rest controller which returns a xml type response <Response> element which has a <Dial> and <Number> element. <Dial> element has a callerId (From Number), and the <Number> element has To Number.
We can get several parameters from the plivo request object sent from Plivo server to our application-
“X-PH-userId” - We can get userId from this parameter.
“CallUUID” - We can get Plivo Call SID from this parameter which is used for making CDR entries in the database.
“CallStatus” - We can get call status from this parameter. We are making a CDR entry when the call status is “completed”.

While making CDR entry to the database we are storing CallSid, provider, owner, client detail, call type and created time. If CallSid starts with “CA” then we store “Twilio” in the provider or else “Plivo”.
The <Record> element is used to turn recording on and recordingSession is passed true to record the whole session.
<Response> <Record recordSession="true" /> <Dial callerId="from"> <Number>To</Number> </Dial></Response>
To make an outgoing call a user needs to be logged in plivo using the username and password from the endpoint -  created using plivoBrowserSdk.client.login(username, password)
On successful updation of the callerId and to number call an outgoing call should be made using plivoBrowserSdk.client.call(to,extraHeaders).
NOTE : The extra headers passed to the above method follows certain rules:
Your field must start with an uppercase letter. Other characters must be in lowercase.
Header name can only contain alphanumeric characters(A-Z, a-z, 0-9)
Header name can have a maximum length of 24 characters
Header value may comprise of alphabets(A..Z, a..z), numerals(0-9), and '%' .
Header value should have a maximum length of 48 characters
After the call is initiated, multiple events are provided by the plivo on Plivo Client instance to handle cases like :
Receive the sent headers as request parameters on client side. The header name-value pairs that do not follow the above rules will not be sent by Plivo.
More info on Plivo Browser SDK -

The task activity will display all the details regarding the upcoming, recents and completed events.
The task activity displays three major things such as:
The data for the upcoming, recent and completed activities is fetched from the SalesKen staging database.
The upcoming activity shows all the events that are upcoming for today.
Api: /v1/task/upcoming/v1 is hit to fetch the data regarding the upcoming events.
ResponseCode : 200 (success), 400 (Bad Request) ,500 (Internal Server Error)
The user Id of a lead is used to fetch the data from the database for the respective lead.

To fetch the data regarding the recent events, from the staging database, we select task.id, task.disposition, task.name, pipeline_stage.name, task.status, deal.name, lead.contacts, task.deal_id, task.task_type is fetched from the the task table.
A left join is performed on the deal table where task.deal_id = ​http://deal.id  and the deal.status should not be deleted.
A left join is performed on the lead table where deal.lead_id = lead.id.
A left join is performed on the pipeline_stage table where task.stage_id = pipleline_stage.id.

The query is then parsed and the data is then iterated over using a hashmap of key and value type of string and string respectively. The data then is set to the respective field of the TASK class, where the task class demands the following properties such as id, startDate, endDate, updatedAt etc.
The recent activity shows all the recent events for today.
Api: /v1/task/recent/v1 is hit to fetch the data regarding recent events.
The user Id is used to fetch the data from the database, where the userId is equal to the rep.skenId.keyword.

To fetch the data regarding the recent events, from the staging database, we select task.name, task.direction, task.disposition, task.duration, lead.phoneNumber, task.status, task.id , lead.companyName from the activity_log_bulk_v16 for a particular userId.
First all the tasks with the given userId are fetched by using the QueryBuilders on the term “rep.skenId.keyword” with must on term “task.callStatus.keyword” is “COMPLETED”.
The completed activity shows all the completed activity for the lead.
Api: /v1/task/completed/v1 is hit to fetch the data regarding recent events.
The userId is used to fetch the data from the staging database.
To fetch the data regarding the completed task event, we use the task.skenId, task.createdAt, task.callStatus, lead.companyName,
This API returns the complete details of a task whose Id user have provided

API returns the complete details of a given taskId like agent name, customer name, customer email, customer phone number , pipeline stage  and coordinates of call along with signal data. Signal data  contains details like color , name and its plotting coordinates over x and y axis of signal for a given task / Call.
EndPoint:<hostname>:8080/api/task/completed/details/{task_id}  task_id  is path param , replace it with callId whose complete details user want to fetch
The userId is used to fetch the user details from the database which API gets from the JWT token.
Left join call with pipeline on attribute call.stage_id , deal with call on attribute call.deal_id ,lead with deal on attribute deal.lead_id and user with call on attribute call.owner
After left joining of above tables select below attribute from different tables
Query used to fetch complete details of the given task

Query : "select call.id, call.recording_url, call.owner as agent_id, u.\"name\" as agent_name,"+ " u.profile_image as agent_image, "+ " TO_CHAR( call.started_at, 'hh12:mi AM' ) as task_start_time, TO_CHAR( call.start_date, 'DD Mon' ) AS task_start_date, l.contact as scp_contact_details, ps.stage_name , call.duration from call left join deal on ​http://deal.id  = call.deal_id left join lead l on l.id = ​http://deal.id  "+ "left join pipeline_stage ps on ps.id = task.stage_id left join user u on ​http://u.id  = task.owner where task.id = "+ taskId + "";
Here taskId is a user provided callId whose details the user wants to fetch.
Above query is used to get details of customer and agents .
To get signal data and plotting coordinates of signal follow below steps
First get provider_call_id details from the call table and then use details to fetch data from s3 having bucketname dummyskensnippet. Parse response which we get from s3 and map into response.
Query used to get provider_call_id from call table :
select provider_call_id from call where id = " + taskId
This API shows the history of completed Call based on given callId.
This API shows the list of  call IDs which were a part of the deal and whose call Id is given by the user.
EndPoint: <hostname>:8080/task/completed/history/{task_id}  task_id  is path param , replace it with taskId whose history user want to fetch
The userId is used to fetch the user details from the database which the API will get from the JWT token.
First create a subquery which fetches deal_id from the call table where id must be equal to given callId.

After getting the result of the query formed in step 2 fetch all details of the call whose deal_id must be present in the result of step 2 subquery and order them in descending order with respect to the attribute id.
Query - select * from call c where c.deal_id in (select c2.deal_id from call  c2 where c2.id = " + taskId + ") and c.id not in (" + taskId + ") order by c.id desc
Post execution of query get callId of all calls which were in the result set of above query.

userId, we received from the authorization header is used for fetching the data from the database.

The attributes that we are fetching are ​http://deal.id , lead.company_name, lead.contacts from deal after performing left join with lead schema on condition deal.lead_id = lead.id, of such deal where deal.owner_id = userid and deal.status!=WON and deal.status!=LOST after ordering in descending order.
Then we will iterate over the result we received after parsing the query and set the respective fields of Lead object and return that ArrayList of Lead objects in response.

If there is any user present, then from the result we received in the above query, we will get manager_id and company_id.

2.1 Now, we will check if there is already a lead present with the phone number we  will receive in the lead object which is coming as a parameter i.e we are querying in the lead table where contact is equal to lead.getPhoneNumber().
2.2 If there is no such lead, then we will insert this lead in the lead table and also we will insert a deal in the deal table with lead_id as the id of the lead we are inserting.

2.3 If there is any lead already present in the database, then we will update   company_name and contacts attributes of that lead with company name and contacts of the lead object we are receiving as parameter, no new deal is going to be inserted for a lead which is already present in the DB.
If there is no such user, then we will give “No manager assigned to this user” in response.

Overview: API authenticates whether  details provided by the user are valid or not  and returns an authentication token.
1 ) Email should be as per standard , it should follow the regex pattern :^[A-Z0-9._%+'-]+@[A-Z0-9.-]+\\.[A-Z0-9]{2,6}$
First API validates whether user provided email is as per standard and post that API will fetch userDetails using user provided email .It uses below  query to fetch user details:

Query : "SELECT user.ID,user.caller_id, user.email, user.is_active, user. PASSWORD, user.profile_image, user.name, user.mobile,   user.languages, ​http://company.id , company.name AS org_name,company.website FROM user JOIN company ON user.company_d = ​http://company.id    WHERE LOWER (user.email) "+ "= LOWER ('" + userEmail + "');
Here userEmail  is userEmail which user has provided
After getting details , API checks if the password provided by the user is the same which is stored into DB using md5 encryption.
After checking the password  API check the user role, whether the user has SALES_ASSOCIATE role or not .

Post checking roles, API fetch few properties from comapny_config table and set in user object . Query fetches property name like AppCallEnabled,ProxyCallEnabled, UploadManualAudio, IsDispositionSkipDisabled ,IsCustomDispositionEnabled, CustomDispositionUrl, CrmProvider.
After setting property in user object It saves data related to auth token in auth_token table if entry is out there , else it updates properties .
INSERT INTO auth_token (  jwt, user_id, is_active, device_id, client_id, created_at, deactivated_at,build_no) VALUES"+ " ( ?, ?, ?, ?, ?, now(), now(),?);
Here values are the following : token (which is UUID), userId,true, device from which user logged in , user name and last build number of application.
UPDATE auth_token set  is_active=true,build_no=? , created_at = now() WHERE id=?
Here Values to be updated are : build number if changed, id is logged in userId
At last, after successfully execution of all  above steps create a JWT token and return in response header.

API logs  out  user from logged in device it internally updates the fsm user token by using Salesken  delete fcm_token API whose  request mapping is “api/v1/notification/fcm_token/delete” and is of type POST. Salesken fcm_token delete API takes the Notification object as input which is formed by setting deviceId, fcm_token and userId.
Hostname of fcm_token API is set in db.properties with key NOTIFICATION_URL
Overview: API validates whether a phone number provided by the user is valid or not .
Along with validation API validate performs the below actions as well which are :
It checks whether the trial period of given user is expired or not
It checks whether a user is active or not
It checks whether the user  has a license  or not.
It checks whether  the company has a valid licence or not.
If all above requirements are met then API validates phone number and returns success. If the phone number is valid API will return success else it would return a bad request.
To check the trial period of a given user is expired or not , API uses below query
Query : select * from company_config oc where companyId in (select user.company_Id from user  where id= "+ userId + " and oc.property_name in('OrganizationStatus','ExpiryDate'))
In the above query get data from company_config  table which contains the value of attribute property name “OrganizationStatus , ExpiryDate” and where company id equals to logged in user company id .
To check whether a user is active or not API uses below query
Query : select * from user iu where is_active = true and id = " + userId;
In above query get user data where id equals to logged in user Id and its is_active attribute is true. If the size of the query resultset is more than 0 then it concludes that the user is active.
To check whether a user has a license or not API  uses below query
Query : select * from user_license ul where ul.user_id =" + userId;
In above query get data from table user_license where user_id  attributes equals to logged in user Id .If size of  query resultset is more than 0 then it concludes that user has license..
To check whether a company has a license or not API  uses below query
Query : select is_paid from license where company_id in (select company_id from \"user\" where id=" + userId+")";

First fetch logged in user company id and then check whether in table license has attribute is_paid as true. If the size of the query resultset is more than 0 then it concludes that the company has an active license.
Users can make a proxy call using this API if the user has the role of SALES_ASSOCIATE.

This API internally uses another API whose endpoint is define in db.properties with key “SALESKEN-TWILIO_URL” which helps proxy call API to make an proxy call or in another words proxy call is a wrapper API which internally calls another API to make calls.
The API defined in SALESKEN-TWILIO_URL is of type post and takes a user object as input.

CRM is the synchronization of data between LeadSquared and Saleksen. There are 2 broad use cases:Reading leads/ deals from CRM to Salesken. Writing tasks performed on Salesken to the CRM and for both these use cases we provide flexibility to configure entity mapping from CRM to Salesken’s.
CRM Module will be used in four different journey's:

Journey 1: The first scenario is post-authorization. In this scenario, the user will select LeadSquared CRM from the salesken web application portal, after the selection of LeadSquared CRM a window will be open, where the user will enter credentials i.e. Access key, Secret key, Calls log API, Async API key. After getting the details we will send a request to the CRM module for post-authorization.
Journey 2: In this scenario, there are two cases when we will sync user details from CRM.
After successfully post-authorization, we will sync all user's details i.e. user id from CRM to salesken DB.
When a new user will create on salesken application.
Journey 3: In this scenario, when the user dials a number from the Salesken application, then the dialed number will be searched by CDR import which makes a request to the CRM module.

Journey 4: In this scenario, After the call end CDR import makes a request to the CRM module for post-call hook. The CRM post-call hook will be used to push tasks on CRM corresponding salesken task. Before pushing the task on CRM we have to check that the current company is subscribing task import feature or not. If not subscribing then we will not push task on CRM.
Architecture Diagram:      Post Authorization:

When the user selects LeadSquared CRM from the Salesken web application portal, he will provide us the credentials i.e Access key, Secret key, Calls log API, Async API key. After getting the details we will validate this data, then this data will be stored in the database with table name company and column name provider_details. if data get stored successfully API response will be HTTP 200 else it will throw an exception.

When the user dials a number from the Salesken application, then the dialed number will be searched by CDR import which makes a request to the CRM module, then CRM module will search the number using Lead Search API and return the response i.e LeadSearchResponse which consists of email, full name, company name, CRM deals. if the number is not found by Lead Search API then we will return.
User sync will be done on user email. We will send a request to CRM and store response details will be stored in the database with table name user and column name provider_details.

The CRM post-call hook will be used to push task on CRM corresponding salesken call object. Before pushing the task on CRM we have to check that the current company is enabled the task import feature or not. After getting a response from CRM, we will create an entry on elk index with the current call object response which we got from CRM with the index name crm_hook_log.
Elastic Index Model: We will create an elk index with the name crm_hook_log to store all CRM post-call logs.

Purpose : Retrieve details of all completed calls from Plivo Platform within a given time range.
Assumption :API will retrieve details of all calls which are completed within a given time range.
Scheduler will call below API in every 30 min or as per schedule

Overview: Create an API that retrieves details of all completed calls from Plivo Platform within a given time range using Plivo API  and store all the details into Salesken DB  with entity name “PlivoCalls”.
Response Codes : 200 (success), 401 (Unauthorized), 400 (Bad Request), 500 (Internal Server Error)
API will take the below query parameter :
·        StartTime (optional) – Helps users to define From which date-time user wants to fetch details.
Default Value – Current time  -  30 min.
·        EndTime (optional) – Helps users to define Till which date-time user wants to fetch details.

·        Limit(Optional) – Helps users to define the number of records to be fetched . As Plivo API  supports retrieval of a maximum 20 records at once , if the user wants to retrieve less than 20 records  then user can pass that number in this query param but If user passes more than 20, query param values will be ignored and  only 20 records will be fetched.

·        Offset (Optional) – User can refer to it as a page number , as total number of records might be more than 20 and at max user can fetch 20 records , if we divide all records into chunks / buckets of 20 then each bucket represents offset  number, starting from 0.

Note : As Limit and Offset is dependent on each other , total_count in Plivo System must be greater than equal to (offset+1)*limit. example – If there are 19 records  for a given time range and user pass limit as 10 and offset as 0 then API will return data from 1 to 10 records and if user pass offset as 1 then it will retrieve data  from 11 to 19 . But if the user selects limit as 20 then for offset 0  API will retrieve all 19 records and for offset greater than  will return empty list / no record .
API Response – “Success” with status code 200. (For successful execution.)

Trial Account - All the trial featured will only be available
Platinum - Select the billing period and forward to the payment gateway
Gold - Select the billing period and forward to the payment gateway
Silver - Select the billing period and forward to the payment gateway.

Managers carry forward with other product related configurations.

Sales managers when adding a new user will get a privilege to attach that user to a new licence.
